The plan: Swim the mile!

We will be hiking slow and steady pace although this is a easy breezy beginner hike. Please note that the trail is rocky and hilly only 1.5 miles to the lake, a total of 3 miles with a refreshing swim @ lake welch at the halfway point, on swimming for about an hour and a half note due to time constructions I cannot wait the time I'm starting is extremely late you should get yourself there early enough to be able to leave on time

What to bring:

Be sure to bring some food, plenty of water, insect repellent, sunglasses, poolbuey, kickboard,  paddles someone please bring a water polo ball.

The weather: 90 degrees

The distance: 3 miles

Meet at the boat launch

(Heals down @ (12:30) is already a late start so no waiting

Note: directions maybe rather Hokey Mcstokey, the meeting place, Sebago boat launch is 2.5 miles North of Reeves medow visitor center.

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

results.description:
Waiting List: The day before an event we tend to have a lot of people drop out so do not be discouraged if you're on the waiting list--there's a good chance you'll be able to join.


Attending List: Please remember that the RSVP list closes at 5pm the day before an event. If you change your RSVP to NO after that time or are a no-show, someone on the waiting list could be left out. We take that very seriously.

Club Hours: C&B sets aside space for us from 12:30pm to 2:30pm so those are the official club hours. Everyone is free to stay longer if they wish.

First-Timers: If it is your first time at C&B, you will have to take a lesson from the range staff. If you are an experienced archer, you must at least stay for the safety portion (no exceptions, range rules). Lessons start at half past the hour so if you miss the 12:30pm, you may have to sit around and wait for the 1:30pm. Please be on time.

Public Transportation: LIRR to Hicksville and then a taxi from the station to C&B (make sure to tell them 11 Commercial St in Hicksville). The train from Penn gets into Hicksville at 11:55 am. The cab rate as of 1/1/14 is $6.50 +$2 for each additional person. Those of you taking the train may wish to post a message to the group to share a cab.

Range Costs: Make sure to mention when you pay for range time you are shooting with the NYC Archery Group to get the CLUB ONLY rates:

$7.00 for the first hour, $5 each additional hour OR $15 to shoot all day
$1.00 for a target
$11 per hour for a rental bow and arrows
$5.00 for a lesson (includes first hour)

Visit the C&B website for the most up-to-date information.

See you on the shooting line!
results.name: New York City Archery Monthly Meetup at C&B

results.description:
** This class is for anyone who is completely new to improv and have been afraid to try it out. **

** You're welcome to stay and watch the Level 2 class that's happening right after this class ends. **

Public speaking is a powerful skill to have. And there is a powerful way to build upon and enhance your public speaking presence and have a good laugh at the same time: by learning how to improvise!

Improv takes focus, a willingness to embrace the group dynamic and a commitment to fostering your sense of play.

Dewey Chaffee, a professional comedian and improvisor, will lead you through each of these areas with skill, kindness and most importantly, patience, creating an environment that is safe, comfortable, and creatively inspiring.

Improv will make you a better listener, a more open and accepting communicator in life, and a master at slinging bullshit when you need to appear more confident than you feel on the inside!

More details here: www.PlayWithDewey.com

Anyone and everyone is welcome! 

(We prefer that you sign up online, so we can get an accurate head count. If you can only pay in-person, please bring exact change.)

-----------------------------------------------

About Dewey Chaffee

Dewey has more than 20 years of improvisation experience. He spent 23 years perfecting his skills as an improv performer for the Walt Disney Company. He's also appeared on Nickelodeon Television and worked as their audience warm up guy for several seasons of TV production.

Currently, he and his husband perform a live improvised comedy drag show called "The Lady Winifred and Didi Show."
results.name: Intro to Improv [LEVEL 1]

results.description:
Meet to share and discuss SF and fantasy writing, books, films, TV shows, the writing process, the publishing industry, etc. with other SF and fantasy writers (both published and unpublished).  We usually have a long and lively discussion, followed by critiques of stories or chapters (if any) that members brought along.  We don't always have stories to critique, but we usually enjoy having hours worth of discussion, so let us know near the beginning of the Meetup if you brought something to have critiqued so we don't use up all our time talking -- time flies when you're having fun!

Further details or topics for this Meetup may be announced later.

As usual, you can bring a chapter or short story for the group to critique, but it's by no means necessary.  If you do bring your MS, try to bring enough paper copies for everyone attending to have one, and if you want us to write comments or corrections on it, then please double-space it.  We usually ask the author to read it aloud (unless you're shy), which is very helpful, because you'd be surprised how often you don't catch your own mistakes until you read your manuscript aloud for the first time! 

For the manuscript (MS) critiques, length is not set in stone, but suggested length is 1500 words, maximum length 3000 words. In pages (Times 12 point font), 1500 words is just under five pages double spaced, or about three pages single-spaced (but you should always double-space to allow room for people to write comments or corrections!)  Don't worry if your MS is longer than 1500 words, you can still bring it, but please keep it under 3,000 words.

For more guidelines on critiques, see http://www.meetup.com/The-Woodbridge-Science-Fiction-Fantasy-Writers-Meetup/about/
results.name: Share and discuss writing with other SF and fantasy writers

group.name: The Woodbridge Science Fiction & Fantasy Writers Meetup

results.description:
Click the link below to purchase tickets to this event: 


https://www.eventbrite.com/e/nyac-experience-inside-the-roosevelt-house-tickets-18670760748

Join New York Adventure Club on Saturday, September 19th, for a private tour of the Roosevelt House in the Upper East Side — the former double townhouse of Franklin, Eleanor and Sara Delano Roosevelt, now owned by Hunter College.

On this experience through the Neo-Georgian landmark designed by architect Charles A. Platt, we'll explore the private spaces where some of the most iconic public policies of the 20th century were shaped -- hear about Franklin’s rise to the presidency after his struggle with polio, Eleanor’s activism for civil rights and human rights, and Sara’s philanthropy. 

As a NYAC-only treat, we'll get to view original documents from the New Deal that are kept locked away from the general public.

Afterwards, we'll grab some food and drinks in the neighborhood!
results.name: NYAC Experience: Inside the Roosevelt House

results.description:
Join us for three hours of figure drawing in the heart of Union Square.

This session is open to sketchers of all levels.


What makes our sessions different? 

• We work in a large, clean, well-lit space. 

• Sketchers can concentrate because our room is quiet while the model is posing.

• (Latecomers can be seated at a break.)


• Every hour we take a break to look each others drawings (if you choose to put yours out.) This is a nonjudgmental and very valuable part of the session. 

• This is a three hour drawing session to work from a live (nude) model.  


• We start with 5 minute poses and work up to 20 minute poses by the end of the session. We take a 5 minute break every 20 minutes. 

• There are seats for everyone tables and several light weight easels. 


• Access to a sink is available for watercolor artist.

• Bring your own materials (no oil or acrylic paint and no sprays please.)

As always if you have any questions please feel free to email me. I look forward to seeing you there. 

Simon

results.description:
As a group, we study a text--a story, poem, or essay, in English, Spanish or Latin--then each child, with your help, writes something inspired by the text. After that, the kids take turns reading their writings out loud while everybody listens in a sacred hush. The simple grace of this ritual changes lives. The kids we work with are the children of Spanish-speaking immigrants living in poverty.

We have welcomed many brilliant authors who provide the texts we study from their writings. To read their testimonials, please see: www.stillwatersinastorm.org/testimonials/. For a quick introduction to Still Waters, including video by CBS Evening News and press from The Huffington Post and The Guardian, please go to: www.stillwatersinastorm.org/about/.
Feel free to bring a friend!
Muchas gracias!
Gratias maximas!
Many thanks!

results.description:
It is important for us as students of spirituality and mysticism to become aware and acquainted with the tremendous resources that are available to us to make our lives more harmonious.

Once we learn to tap these inner resources, living will be an invigorating affair continuing and picking up where we left off in previous life experiences and thereby advancing and expanding the consciousness.

We need to keep foremost in our consciousness certain principles, conditions and laws to gain access to spiritual tools and to arrive at permanent solutions to life's challenges.

Through lectures, participation in meditation, and visualization exercises, we will be given the opportunity to experience the value of discussing these principles in a group setting.

Facilitating the discussions will be Dr. Lonnie Edwards, Vice President of the EGL Board of Directors, and author of Spiritual Laws that Govern Humanity and the Universe.

(www.facebook.com/Spiritual.Laws)

2:00pm

Lower Manhattan, Chinatown, Little Italy, and SoHo

When

Sat, September 19, 2pm – 5pm


Where

Federal Hall, 26 Wall Street, New York, NY 10005 (map)


Description
Free Tours by Foot is partnering with Visit New York Tours in offering a multi-neighborh​ood tour of the Lower Manhattan area. The tour begins on Wall Street, where you will see the New York Stock Exchange and Trinity Church before moving on the the World Trade Center and City Hall. We then move on by subway to visit the largest Chinatown in the United States. Following Chinatown, the tour will continue on through Little Italy and on to SoHo. Reservations Required RESERVE NOW

So Join Free Tours by Foot and Visit New York Tours on this 3 hour sight-filled adventure through Lower Manhattan. You will have the opportunity to savor some classic New York foods as well as visit parts of neighborhoods that a hop-on, hop-off buses never venture into.

"Tours by Foot"  is a pay what you wish tour.  It is not a free tour unless you decide not to contribute anything.  If three hours is too much, you are free to leave the tour anytime you so desire.  You must go online and reserve a spot for yourself.  If you hesitate too long they might be full and you will be on stand-by. 

Let me know if you intend to go.  Please tell me if you have reserved a spot for yourself.   IF MORE THAN 6 PEOPLE RESERVE A SPOT ........ and we are all from "Meetup"......  I must let them know and register as a group!!!
results.name: Join "Tours by Foot" of  Lower Mannhatten, China Town, Little Italy, and SoHo

results.description:
<a href="http://photos1.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/5/a/d/e/highres_64103262.jpeg"></a>

Hi Everyone,


Our first 1-day Tournament of the season is here!! RSVP while there are spots available!!

Get plenty of touches on the ball and a chance to win 1st. place championship medals!

See details below:

How long will the Tournament last?

Approximately 3.5  hours depending on the amount of teams registered.

What are the rules and level of play?

- 7vs7 (includes the goalkeeper). All teams will have 2 to 3 substitutes.

- CO-ED (no minimum girls required on field)

- 6'x12' size goals.

- Level is intermediate to advance. If you played at a college level or similar, you would be considered Advanced.

- No slide tackles.

-Only turf shoes, indoor shoes or running sneakers.

-3 points for a win, 1 for a tie and 0 for a loss. The teams in the Final Round games are decided by points, goal difference then goals scored.

-We'll keep track of scores. The goals are full size, so if you are a goalkeeper please let us know. Otherwise, teammates will rotate being goalkeeper.

-Everyone will be randomly placed on a team. If you would like to be placed with a particular team, please let us know in the comment section when you rsvp on the top right corner; we will try to accommodate everyone. Also, if you would like to bring your own team, please RSVP for you+9 and pay the total via paypal.

How do I join?
There are 2 ways to join:

1. The first way to join is as a free agent. To join as a free agent please rsvp on this page and we will place you on a team. If you would like to be placed with a friend on the same team, please let us know. We will try to accommodate everyone :)

2. The second way to join is as a team. If you would like to register your team please rsvp on this page for you+ 9 guests and pay the total amount via paypal.

How will the tourney work?

- We are looking to register 3 to 4 teams. The format varies depending on the amount of teams registered. See this link for the format: Tournament Formats

What's included?
- Hired referees
- Permit fees
- Tournament and website administration

- Medals for 1st place winners

What are the prizes?

- Easch player in the winning team receives medals and gains bragging rights :)

What should you bring?

-Please use cleats or turf shoes and lots of water.

-A white t-shirt, a red t-shirt and a blue t-shirt.

What is the refund policy?

Field Location:Click here for: Field Location Map.To see an aerial view of the field on Bing Maps: Aerial Map

DirectionsYou can get to Randall's Island by car, bus, walking or biking. Here is the link to the directions: Directions to Randall's Island

The best ways to get there are:

-Taking the A,C,D, 4,5 or 6 train to 125th st stop and walking or biking east over the RFK Bridge.

-Also, taking the M35 bus from the NW corner of 125th Street and Lexington Ave.

If you have any questions about getting there please e-mail or all us at[masked]

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Fee:Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.


Cancellations/Refunds: If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for the next game. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!


Waiting List: If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will be sent an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has just openned :).

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

SMR 2015 Family Campout Registration is OPEN

The second annual SMR Family Campout will take place September 19-20th at Summit Field (rain date a week later). Oriented toward families with children up to 12 years of age, the overnight camping and educational program is run by the Conservancy with the assistance of the Essex County Department of Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Affairs. Last year’s program was attended by 65 parents and children and was a great success. Space in the program is limited to around 35 families. Immerse yourself in the simple beauty and majesty of our forest. Experience the Reservation through the seasoned eyes of our nature experts. Open your children’s minds to all the woods have to offer. Activities likely to include: Guided nature hikes Saturday and Sunday

Tours of the Wildflower and Forest Preserve Bike/scooter fun ride

Evening program

Campfire and storytelling

Yoga session

Scavenger hunt

And more!

For more information and register, go to:
http://www.somocon.org/2015-smr-family-campout/

About the Founder:  Ron Gross is the founder of "Conversations New York." He's been organizing exciting, important CONVERSATIONS for 20 years, and currently holds them regularly on the Columbia University campus and elsewhere through the city. He's the author of 23 books on LIFELONG LEARNING. He was recently honored for lifetime achievement in the field by the International Society for Self-Directed Learning. The late Buckminster Fuller said of Ron's work: “If humanity is to pass safely through its present crisis on earth, it will be because a majority of individuals are now doing their own thinking. Ronald Gross’ work has pioneered in improving the climate for such thinking in the United States.”

results.description:
>>>> PURCHASE TICKETS HERE <<<<

PLEASE BYPASS the RSVP button at right and register directly above. If you are a dues-paying Member of Out Professionals, this assures you no-cost or low-cost admission to this event. (Nonmembers are always welcome, but nonmember rates apply if you are just part of our Meetup group.) For a full year of Member savings and other career benefits, join Out Professionals here. 


DISCOVER THE HIDDEN WEST CHELSEA ON OUT PROFESSIONALS' NEW WALKING TOUR AND MIXER.


On Saturday, September 19, Out Professionals invites you to discover the hidden charms of West Chelsea.

Beginning in the 18th century as one man’s farm, this West Chelsea neighborhood is a beautiful enclave of elegant 19th century New York. Houses survive in the Federal, Greek-Revival, and Italianate styles. One centerpiece of the neighborhood is the 180-year-old General Theological Seminary, still a picturesque center of learning.

The new look in world-class architecture is also here — eye-catching structures by Frank Gehry, Annabelle Selldorf, and Jean Nouvel. Art sites include such galleries as those of Matthew Marks, Pat Hearn, Morris Healy, and Annina Nosei. The newest museum on the block is the Chelsea Art Museum.

Highlights of the walk include:


• How Chelsea got its name and how Chelsea Piers came to be

• The block-square campus of General Theological Seminary

• The Chelsea Hotel and its notorious past

• The internationally celebrated West Chelsea Gallery District

• Celebrities of the West Chelsea neighborhood

After exploring these far-west streets, our tour ends at the newest work of art, the remarkably-transformed High Line Park. After hearing about its history and design, tour-takers can enjoy climbing up to see this elevated wonderland and the beautiful views within and around it.

After the tour, we’ll stop for refreshments at a relaxed mixer near the High Line.

Out Professionals’ private Walking Tour/Mixer series is designed for us — and you — by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Joyce teaches New York history at New York University and the New School.


WHERE

We meet at 20th Street & 9th Avenue, at the northwest corner at La Bergamote. Subway: C/E to 23rd Street. Directions from where you are: hopstop.com

WHAT’S UP

Tour begins at 2 p.m. sharp, rain or shine. Open-ended mixer begins about 4 p.m. at a nearby lounge; refreshments on your own.

ADMISSION

Nonmember, $25. Dues-paying OP Member, just $15. OP Member plus one guest, $35. The personalized nature of our tours requires that the number of participants be limited. Avoid disappointment; register now.

IT PAYS TO BE AN OP MEMBER!

A one-year individual Out Professionals Membership (new or renewal) PLUS admission to “Hidden Charms of Chelsea” is yours for just $80. And remember, that buys you a year’s worth of low-cost or no-cost networking and socializing. Order here.

results.description:
Note: If you are planning on attending this meetup please RSVP. I want to be able to know how many people are coming for a given session. Thank you.

I often see members of this group looking for time to study English, so I would like to give the non-native English speakers in our group an opportunity to improve their English just like they have given us the chance to improve our Chinese, Japanese, or Korean skills.

I also hope that by extending this opportunity, we will encourage more native speakers of Chinese, Japanese, and Korean to participate and aid our CJK practice on Wednesdays.

Our practice will include games, discussion, and reading activities. Please look for a notice from me about what activities we will doing each Saturday.

Any and all suggestions for methods, activities, etc. are welcome.

This group was created to function as an exchange. We help you and you help us.

For native speakers of Chinese, Japanese, or Korean, we hope that you will attend our meeting on Wednesday to help our language learners.

Finally, for any native English speakers who are interested in helping, please contact me (Carl) if you want to help out. Please contact me so that we can meet on Wednesday and potential volunteer opportunities. We want to create a friendly and engaging atmosphere but I would like to talk with you for a brief moment during the week before you participate as a volunteer. 

If you have any questions, comments, or concerns, feel free to contact me (Carl).

How to find us...

Go to 53rd street and Lexington Ave. The building is across the street from a CVS pharmacy on 53rd St, there are two main entrances. The top entrance in the picture is on 53rd St between Lexington avenue and 3rd avenue. The bottom entrance is on the corner of 53rd St and Lexington avenue. The building is called the Citigroup Center but the area where we sit is also called the Atrium Shops and Cafes. Which is located on the bottom floor: a big open area which has many round and square tables and chairs. The ZIP CODE is 10022. If you still have problems finding us look for a high rise glass building. Barnes and Nobles and 24 Hr Fitness are also located in the same building except on the upper level. If you enter on the upper levels then take the escalator down to ground floor where all the people and tables are.

results.description:
Would you like to be healthier and more relaxed and joyful…….letting go of stress and the burdens of a busy mind?

If so, come and join us for the Open Heart Meditation and Reiki Tummo energy balancing treatment. You will feel more relaxed and peaceful as Divine energy is channeled to everyone simultaneously.

What is Reiki energy healing?

Reiki is a simple way of channeling high vibration energy for healing purposes for ourselves or others. It clears blockages in our energy channels so that our physical body can be healthier. The practitioner does not use his/her energy, but is just a channel through which the energy flows. Reiki Tummo goes beyond traditional Reiki in that it is not just a healing modality, but also helps us to grow spiritually by opening our spiritual heart which is our connection to the Creator. Reiki Tummo also uses kundalini and earth energy for a deeper and gentler acceleration of cleansing and spiritual growth.

What else do I need to know?

Donations are gratefully accepted, but if you can't donate please feel free to come. Space is very limited so register early. Repeaters are always welcome. You may bring interested guests.

Open Heart and Reiki TUMMO Alumni can join for free.

Please note that this is not a Reiki circle to channel Usui.  You will be experiencing Reiki TUMMO by Padmacahaya alumni only.

Call Ann at[masked] or email by 9am @ [masked] for more information

Heart Smiles,

the NYC Group

results.description:
** This class is for those of you who have taken Improv Level 1 at least once. **

** If you want a longer warm-up, you can drop in for FREE on the Level 1 workshop taking place an hour before this. **

In this class, Dewey will help you take the basic elements of improv fundamentals learned in Level 1 and apply them toward building great scenes that engage an audience. 

You will learn the basic structure of comedic scenes and work on using “yes, and…” to discover and heighten the funny, understand how to make strong offers, establish who/what/where, heighten the funniest choices, and edit scenes.

If we get a consistent group, we might even consider putting on a show that you will perform in front of your friends and family as the culmination of your hard work in class.

More details here: www.PlayWithDewey.com

(We prefer that you sign up online, so we can get an accurate head count. If you can only pay in-person, please bring exact change.)

He's been organizing exciting, important CONVERSATIONS for 20 years, and currently holds them regularly on the Columbia University campus and elsewhere through the city. He's the author of 23 books on LIFELONG LEARNING. He was recently honored for lifetime achievement in the field by the International Society for Self-Directed Learning. The late Buckminster Fuller said of Ron's work: “If humanity is to pass safely through its present crisis on earth, it will be because a majority of individuals are now doing their own thinking. Ronald Gross’ work has pioneered in improving the climate for such thinking in the United States.”

results.description:
This Event: 

The aim of this weekly event is to offer a place where Python developers and learners can come and ask questions or give help. 

Individuals of all programming skill levels are welcome. 

It is suggested that you bring your own laptop. If you don't have access to a laptop and want to attend, please let Paul Logston know and he will see about getting you a laptop for the day.

This event is free. 

This event is not a tutorial. Tutorials hosted by Learn Python NYC are labeled as tutorials.

Resources:

Here are some learning resources and free text editor / IDE suggestions.

https://github.com/logston/NYCPythonSOH/blob/master/resources.rst 

Detailed Directions to us:

As you enter the building located at 568 Broadway, New York, NY 10012 you will need to provide ID and your destination (Fueled Collective, 11th Floor) to the front desk. They will provide you with a sticker badge. Take one of the elevators (located to the right of the front desk) to the 11th floor. We will be in the Deerbrook conference room.

10-a-side. 2 teams, 75min game. Arrive early to warm up, and be ready to start at 2pm.


ALL players need to bring a white and black t-shirt and  ball.


It's a large field and some players may need the option to sub. If you're a dedicated goalkeeper let us know.


****************************************************************

DETAILS:

• Played in a friendly environment. Pass the ball have fun.

• No rough tackles or play. Players are expected to bring a positive attitude, no screaming at/or berating team mates.

•  BRING A BALL. If you hit a ball into the river, you'll need to replace it!  If there aren't any dedicated goalkeepers playing, we rotate in goal every 5 mins.

• No metal cleats. Only turf or molded cleats.


• If you arrive late, pls wait until a break in the game. Inserting players in the middle of the game disrupts the flow, and it's not fair to those that arrive on time.


Payment goes toward field permit, equipment and fees. 

See you at the pitch!


Note: The is a 2/3 regulation size field with full size goals. Not suitable for beginner level or inexperienced players.

By joining this group and attending events you agree to the Waiver Of Liability.

results.description:
NOTE: PLEASE ONLY RSVP IF ARE ALSO ABLE TO ATTEND A VOLUNTEER ORIENTATION AT THE APOLLO THEATER ON FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 18TH FROM 6PM - 8PM & YOU DEFINITELY KNOW YOU'RE AVAILABLE TO HELP FOR THE REQUESTED TIME BLOCK (2PM - 6PM) ON SEPTEMBER 19TH.


The Apollo Theater is hosting it's 3rd Annual community initiative focused on family health and wellness - Harlem Healthy Soul Festival. Sponsored by Coca-Cola, Harlem Healthy Soul Festival is designed to serve as a platform for Harlem families to learn about the numerous community health resources to live active and healthy lives.


This day long, free event will take place on Saturday, September 19th beginning at noon and will transform 126th Street behind the Apollo, into a block party filled with music, entertainment, celebrity performances, health and educational resources and family fun. Families are encouraged to participate in an array of activities such as health screenings, nutrition-focused cooking demonstrations, celebrity performances, and exercise modules. EmblemHealth and Manhattan’s Physician Group will also provide free health screenings.

For more information about the festival, performances, & celebrity updates, please visit www.harlemhealthy.com.

Our Meetup
In this unique community service opportunity, 10 volunteers from 2pm to 6pm will be assisting the Apollo Theater event organizers with operational duties of the festival, which will include troubleshooting and aiding the festival vendors, escorting talent to and from the green room area to the stage and general duties that may come with an event of this nature. <a>HarlemGo side note:</a> This also is an EXCELLENT TIME to do some professional networking as well!

PLEASE ONLY RSVP IF ARE ALSO ABLE TO ATTEND A VOLUNTEER ORIENTATION AT THE APOLLO THEATER ON FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 18TH FROM 6PM - 8PM & YOU DEFINITELY KNOW YOU'RE AVAILABLE TO HELP FOR THE REQUESTED TIME BLOCK (2PM - 6PM) ON SEPTEMBER 19TH.

<a>Please read:</a>


The day of the festival, please try to arrive for sign-in 15 minutes prior to the start of your commitment (1:45pm). Please only RSVP if you know you are able to help for the entire time from 2pm - 6pm. Volunteers should be energetic and comfortable working/walking in outdoor conditions (rain or shine). Wear comfortable clothing & shoes. Lunch will be provided, and each volunteer will receive a festival T-shirt.

That's pretty much it. If there are any questions, feel free to post them in the comments/notifications section below or give Daniel a call/text at[masked] if you're running late, need directions, etc. Thanks!

results.description:
We're very excited to announce our second meetup at the OSA Community Center! This is our furthest Uptown meetup yet. OSA is short for Our Saviour's Attonement (Lutheran Church), however, do not let that dissuade you if you follow a certain religion -our use of the community center is of no religious affiliation! This is a Saturday afternoon of tabletop gaming, welcome to all. RSVP as soon as you can commit, because space is limited to 30 people!

If you haven't attended our other meetups, you can expect to play tabletop games of all sorts; examples include Carcassonne, The Resistance, Castles of Burgundy, Settlers of Catan, Lords of Waterdeep, Agricola, Through the Ages, Magic the Gathering, etc. Feel free to bring any games that you'd like to play with other Uptown Gamers.


Our group is renting this space, so, unlike our other meetups to date, I will have to collect an 8 dollar contribution upon attendance. This will be a good venue for our group because we will not feel obligated to buy food or drinks as we do when we have events at bars/restaurants. The good news, though, is that we are allowed to bring food and (non-alcoholic) beverages into the space, as long as we clean up after ourselves.


Our space will be through the southern entrance, and up the stairs in the balcony room. The space is well lit, and has nice folding tables and chairs which will be very conducive to table top gaming. As I mentioned before, the space is limited to 30 people, so I'd ask that you do not RSVP unless you are reasonably certain that you can attend -this is also important because of the contributions that we'll need to collect in order to keep renting this center.

As always, Uptown Gamers Unite!
results.how_to_find_us: 178 Bennet Ave, Southern entrance and up the stairs to the 2nd floor.
results.name: OSA Community Center, the Anticipated Sequel

results.description:
In honor of the great American author F. Scott Fitzgerald's 119th birthday (Sept. 24), we're going to spend a Saturday visiting some of Fitzgerald's old haunts in New York.

Educated at Princeton, Fitzgerald spent his college and post-college years in pre-Prohibition New York. His first three novels (This Side of Paradise, The Beautiful and the Damned, The Great Gatsby) and several of his short stories took place in Jazz Age New York and the bars, clubs and hotels he frequented were practically characters in his works. Needless to say, Fitzgerald's chronicles of the "Lost Generation" of post-World War I and pre-Depression involved a lot of drinking.

Most of these venues are long gone but some remain and we'll visit them on this meetup. We'll start things at Wolfgang's Steakhouse, 4 Park Ave., the former bar of the old Vanderbilt Hotel. From there, it's up to Terminal City near Grand Central Station and a visit to the bars at the Grand Hyatt--the former Commodore Hotel--and the Roosevelt Hotel, the last of the Terminal City hotels.

Then we'll hit the recently re-opened Knickerbocker Hotel, site of one of the most pivotal scenes in 20th century American Literature, crafted by Fitzgerald, stopping at some other landmarks from Fitzgerald's New York trilogy along the way.

The meetup will include relevant readings from Fitzgerald's works. Please join us in raising a glass to and celebrating the all too brief life of a great American author.
results.name: September Meetup: F. Scott Fitzgerald's New York

results.description:
Come play some great symphonies with us, without any pressure to practice or perform! The Reading Orchestra is back with our first session of the fall. We will spend an afternoon reading through Beethoven Symphony No. 7 and Haydn Symphony No. 104.

Seriously, no need to prepare or anything, just show up and play! Don't worry if you can't play all the notes or even half of the notes, as long as you're having fun playing these great pieces of music you are in the right place. You won't find many opportunities like this in Westchester, or really anywhere!


We do ask for a contribution to help cover space rental and admin costs. $20 for the general public, $10 for students/seniors/NewWSO members. Bring friends! 

It helps if you register in advance so that we know that instruments to expect. Please register, get more information, obtain music, and optionally pay in advance here: http://newsymphony.org/readingorchestra.html

Saturday, September 19 at 2:30 pm

Enjoy an afternoon of music with the Dixieland Express Jazz Band!

The Dixieland Express Jazz Band is a division of the Really Terrible Orchestra of Westchester.  The Band was started 3 years ago by Dr. Norman Weiss who plays the tenor banjo.   The band consists of 13 musicians and one vocalist.  The group currently includes percussion, an Irish drum (bohdran), saxophone, trumpet, cornet, keyboard, electric guitar, bass guitar, clarinet, two banjos and an accordion. The Band has played in many venues throughout Westchester and has been popular with all age groups who seem to love this fun music which has persisted in popularity since the 1910's.

results.description:
The Story Only You Can Tell – Screenplay Immersion


http:// https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xwW7R9Xkkk0

MEET GiGi Next SATURDAY

www.newwaywriter.com 

WHAT YOU WILL LEARN:

No matter how personal the story, there are essential elements that all screenplays must include.

* Creating a multi-dimensional story: Is your story interesting and layered or is it linear in its execution?

* Character development: Are your characters specific and flawed or shallow and predictable?

* Dialogue: Does it pop off of the page? What are the inherent differences in the way a male and female speak?

* A sustainable premise: Does your story fall apart mid way through your script?

* Stakes: Are they high enough? Do they challenge your protagonist?

* Formatting a script: How many acts is a screenplay? How many pages? Where does the inciting incident come into play?

* The First 5 Pages: Do your first 5 pages excite the reader to continue to read?

* The World: Is the world of you story coming through? Is it established in the first few scenes?

We will discuss these among other fundamentals for crafting a strong screenplay.

WHO IS IT FOR:

The 2 hour intensive workshop is appropriate for both emerging and seasoned writers.

www.newwaywriter.com 

BIO:

GiGi New is a film and television writer. A finalist for The Disney Fellowship, she began her career as an assistant on Everybody Loves Raymond, and moved on to writing for the award winning Nickelodeon family series The Brothers Garcia. She worked for producers Gavin Polone (Curb Your Enthusiasm, Gilmore Girls), Wally Wallodarsky, and Maya Forbes (The Simpsons, Diary of a Wimpy Kid, Infinitely Polar Bear ) on the FOX series The Ortega’s.


She has also developed numerous features for several studios and independent producers, among them: Aqua Entertainment, Gunn Films, The Walt Disney Company, Maya Entertainment, Avalanche Entertainment, and Underground Films.


Her feature, Public Emily, was optioned in 2015 and is set to film in 2016. She is also developing a feature length script with the producers of Bedtime Stories and Freaky Friday and her original TV spec, Whaite-less, is currently being shopped to studios.


GiGi has been a script consultant for the past 8 years and her clients have ranged from novices to professional writers, such as Garrison Keillor.

results.description:
From Amazon.com review:


"Welcome to the Fisherman's Rest, a little bar off the Sasoon Dock in Bombay where Mr. Subramaniam spins his tales for a select audience. This is the setting for Vikram Chandra's collection of seven short stories, Love and Longing in Bombay, and Subramaniam is Chandra's Scheherezade. In these stories, Chandra has covered the gamut of genres: there is a ghost story, a love story, a murder mystery, and a crime story, each tale joined to the others by the voice of the elusive narrator. In "Shakti," a discussion about real estate leads to the story of a soldier who must exorcise a ghostly child from his family home. In the final story, "Shanti," a young woman's despair about the state of the country becomes a springboard for a tale of love and hope.

Love and Longing in Bombay is a mesmerizing collection, filled with fully rounded characters and stories that resonate long after the book is back on the shelf. Chandra's prose is luminous, his tales satisfying. Scheherezade would be impressed.
results.name: Discuss Vikram Chandra's "Love and Longing in Bombay: Stories"

results.description:
For our September meetup, Lee Mandell and David Goldstein, Hydroponocists at Boswyck Farms, talk to us about the lessons learned from bootstrapping a  business and building hydroponics systems locally since 2008. This month, Boswyck Farms will be closing its doors, and subsequently after our meetup, Boswyck will be hosting their final party.

About Boswyck Farms


Boswyck Farms is a design agency for hydroponic growing systems. We use hydroponics to share the art of urban farming with those who want better access to fresh, healthy produce.

We work with schools and community-based organizations to create farms of any size in any space and support hands-on science education. It’s our goal to bring sustainable growing methods directly into the hands of the people.

We love farming, but we’re not going to do it for you. We want to teach you to grow food, and help you to develop an urban agriculture program that serves your community. From introductory knowledge to design, construction, and job skills training, we’re here for you.


http://www.boswyckfarms.org/
results.name: Boswyck Farms: Lessons in Bootstrapping, Hydroponics Tour, & Afterparty (FULL)

results.description:
Brookdale Park for this week ONLY.  Our usual spot has an arts & crafts fair.  We'll play by the entrance near the opposing baseball fields (like last time we played there)

I keep an eye on the weather and the field.  In the case of inclement weather - I try to make a determination as early as possible - preferably 24+ hours in advance, or by noon the day of if it's still questionable.  If we are not meeting, I will actually cancel the event page and send out an email.  If you are not signed up to receive emails, check the site, or text me[masked]


Basic Ground Rules for Participation


• no need to respond at all if you can't/don't want to play

• if you do respond IN, please come unless something really urgent comes up (hangovers or better offers from your cooler friends not accepted for absences!)


• If you suck at Ultimate... you are more than welcome. This is open to ALL skill levels, ages etc.   If you're really good, please pretend you suck every once in a while for the benefit of the rest of us! We're just here to run around and have fun. We all want to score and win but if you want to win at all costs, this is not the game for you.

• The trick with this group is making sure we have enough to play, so those who do show up don't waste a trip, so please make the effort this year to be honest with yourself and us about if you can/want to come down so we can make the right call for GAME ON or GAME OFF.  If you are a "maybe" please indicate that via the comment section with a brief explanation (ie 80% chance I'll be there...).  If you RSVP and are then unable to attend, please update your RSVP as soon as possible.



What is Ultimate Frisbee?  In a nutshell <borrowed from Wiki> :

Ultimate is a limited-contact team field sport played with a disc (frisbee). Points are scored by passing the disc to a teammate in the opposing end zone. Other basic rules are that players must not take steps while holding the disc (maintain a pivot), and interceptions and incomplete passes are turnovers.

Closest analogy I could come up with = a mix of basketball and football, but played with a frisbee.  You do not need to be an expert frisbee player/thrower etc. - it's all about having fun.
results.name: Saturday Ultimate Frisbee (Montclair) Brook Dale Park this Saturday!

results.description:
This meeting is for those of us who write fiction, and who have special problems and requirements (such as creating scenes, inserting conflict in the story, word painting or character development).


Bring a piece to read and discuss, up to 1500 words, or simply bring yourself.


Genres covered are art fiction, literary, upscale fiction, women fiction, dark fiction, all kinds of mysteries, speculative fiction (fantasy, urban fantasy, horror and sci-fi), romance (all kinds, including historical, regent, sexy and erotica), screenplays for fiction movies, western-themes fiction, etc.

Fiction can be for children, middle graders (MD), young adults (YA), new adults, and adults. Illustrated children books and graphic novels of fictional character too.

Short stories, flash fiction, novels and novellas welcome.


Poetry is always welcome.

Goodness! Did I include everything?


Best,

Sidney Nesti

This is a walking tour in Central Harlem. Join us and explore the word-class visual vocabulary in the largest neighborhood of Manhattan. We will explore its storied past, interesting present and visualize the promising future of this dynamic community.

Itinerary:

• The Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture 
• Harlem Hospital Mural 
• Abyssinian Baptist Church 
• Strivers Row (architectural gem of the community) 
• Harlem's Walk of Fame 
• The Apollo Theater 
• And Much More 

We will explore these and more sights using the visual links immediate to the location.

Reservations:
Please RSVP. If you later realize you will not be able to attend please change your reservation.

Where:
Participants meet with the guide (Juan J.) ten minutes before tour begins in front of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture map here. Walk concludes at the Apollo Theater; map here.

Cost:
This tour has a market value of $20 per person. You are not charged. At the end of the tour you can put a value to the information presented in the form of a gratuity.

Some of the Sights we will experience:

I look forward to meeting you and showing you a great time in a great section of New York!

NO CLEATS OR PLASTIC STUDS ALLOWED

           PICK-UP CO-ED SOCCER GAMES @ CHELSEA PARK  

                                     Check our Facebook page:

          facebook.com/ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CL2p8P21Zoc

DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for levels and people that prefer to play a competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

There will be 2 teams on the field and we will play TWO games, 30 minutes/Halves. At the end of the first 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play again. Please check your email or our meetup message board on friday night or before 12.00pm on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

Power shots allowed, just please don't do it 5 feet away from goal.

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game and maybe a two game ban.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Location:

CHELSEA PARK.

Between 27th and 28th street and 10th Avenue.

Take A, C or E to 23rd St and 8th Ave and walk to 10th Ave and 27th St or any subway line to 34th St and Penn Station and walk for about 8 minutes to 28th St and 10th Ave.

Call me if you can’t find the field - [masked] Manny S. 

What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.25 when you RSVP. This $9.25 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.


After the game we'll go to Molly Wee for a pint or two:

                             Molly Wee Restaurant

                                       402 8th Ave,

results.description:
We will be continuing the discussion from our last meeting, centering around feminism within minority groups. Posted below are the three articles we discussed, as well as two additional articles (so if members from our last meeting return, there is new material to read). Also, there has been some confusion as to where exactly we meet in The Grey Dog. Our meetings take place all the way in the back, right where the restroom is located. I hope this clears things up and we hope to see you there!

As a black feminist, I see how the wider movement fails women like my mother: http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/dec/09/black-feminist-movement-fails-women-black-minority

Race is a feminist issue: http://www.sparksummit.com/2013/01/01/race-is-a-feminist-issue/

2013 was a big year for feminism, but the movement still alienates minorities: http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/dec/16/feminism-minority-voices-2013-inclusion

The Problem with making celebrities like Patricia Arquette the face of feminism: http://thinkprogress.org/culture/2015/02/23/3625824/problem-celebrity-feminists/

Why we need to talk about diversity differently: http://fortune.com/2015/02/27/why-we-need-to-talk-about-diversity-differently/

Dear Friends,

Enclosed are details for our next concert, scheduled for Saturday, September 19th, 2015:

OPENING COMMENTS

1.  Intermezzo in B minor (Opus 119, No. 1)- J. Brahms, Bagatelle in E flat major (Opus 126, No. 3)- L.V. Beethoven:  Nancy M. Williams (Piano)

2.  Mattinata- R. Leoncavallo, Les Chemins de la mer- P. Kaelin: Eugenia Cymballa (Soprano), Chaim Frieberg (Piano)

3.  Violin Sonata No. 1, Op. 12 (Rondo)-L.V. Beethoven: Somer Taylor (Violin), Alan Fricke (Piano)


4.  Rondo Alla Turca- W.A. Mozart, Autumn Leaves- J. Kosma: Eugenia Cymballa (Piano)

5.  Avinu's Joyful Blues (medley of Bach, Blues, and Jewish liturgy)- arr. D.W. Savin: Daniel Wolf Savin (Bass)

INTERMISSION


6.  Danzas Espanola (Zambra, Oriental)- E. Granados: Dick LaVine (Dance), Serena LaVine (Dance), Marilyn Reichstein (Piano)

7.  The Musical Snuff-Box, Op. 32 (Valse-Joke)-A.K. Liadov, In the Monastery- A.P. Borodin: Tatiana Viscun (Piano)

8.  Bashanah- E. Manor, Simkhe Toyre Time- M. Warshavsky: Elliot Neibch (Violin), Amy Koo (Piano), Doug Makofka (Accordion), Matthew Carlson (Bass), Hau C. Le (Guitar), Vanessa Hannah Bright (Soprano), Vanessa Torres (Soprano), Premila Reddy (Alto), Toshiko Jones (Alto), Celeste Chau (Alto), Brian Alvarado (Tenor), Mary Abraham (Tenor), Randall Trombley (Baritone), Braeden O'Scleari (Baritone), Oscar Segal (Baritone)

ACMA Concert Location Details:

DiMenna Center for Classical Music, Norman S. Benzaquen Hall (2nd Floor)
450 West 37th Street (between 9th and 10th Avenues), New York, NY 10018

If you have any questions regarding this event, please email me at [masked].

We will start as close to 4:00 p.m. as possible. Your punctuality is greatly appreciated.

Transportation

The DiMenna Center is conveniently located on 37th Street between 9th and 10th Avenues, within minutes of Port Authority, Penn Station, and Grand Central Station transportation hubs.

Subway:

A, C, E trains to 34th Street and 8th Avenue

1, 2, 3, LIRR trains to 34th Street and 7th Avenue

Bus:

N, R, Q, B, D, F, M trains to 34th Street and 6th Avenue

N, Q, R, S, 1, 2, 3, 7 trains to Times Square 42nd Street and 7th Avenue

M11 bus to 38th Street and 9th Avenue

M42 bus to 42nd Street and 10th Avenue

Contributions

We suggest a $5.00 contribution per person, to be directly applied towards payment of the hall rental. Contributions are voluntary, and any amount is greatly appreciated.

For Performers (Please read the Performance Tips page on the ACMA website):

What is the high point of your piece? Every musical and dramatic work takes its audience on a journey, generally consisting of the following elements:

1-) Introduction and elaboration: The central melodic theme is introduced and often repeated, in identical fashion or with variation. The mood of the piece is presented and established via use of dynamics, tempo and melodic arc.

The performer must draw in the audience at this point, either with a compelling narrative subtext, or strong emotional message. Also, the performer must build gradual tension (when applicable), leading the audience to the musical climax.

2-) Climax: The highest emotional point of the work, usually occurring 2/3 to ¾ into the piece. Requires maximum expression and melodic emphasis to evoke a desired reaction or response from the audience. Also considered a reward point, or tension release for the audience.

The performer should fully understand the climactic point of the piece, and clearly highlight this point via the use of tone, dynamic expression and musical touch. The importance of the climax for audience understanding and satisfaction cannot be underestimated.

3-) Resolution: The conclusion of the piece, during which all unresolved musical elements are resolved in a decisive manner.

The performer must prepare the audience for the eventual end of the musical journey, a return to reality. Musical cues which aid this transition include:

·  gradual decrescendo and diminuendo

·  a clear a decisive  end point , so as to not leave the audience with an uneasy feeling of something unresolved

Entertain your audience: Great entertainers (actors, singers, etc.) put their unique personality into every performance. If you want to make a memorable impression upon your audience, introduce a new, unique perspective on your piece. Once you truly own your piece, it should carry the inimitable stamp of your personality, but also sound as if it is being performed for the first time.

Select pieces that are personally meaningful to you, and allow for your maximum expression as both performer and entertainer.

Performances do not have to be memorized, or note-perfect. However, as a courtesy to your audience, please present a work that you have studied attentively, and can play to its completion.

If you make a mistake during your performance, please continue to play without stopping. Apologizing, repeating a previously played section, or stopping will only call more attention to your mistake.

results.description:
Learn the discipline of Meditation to cultivate of a rich inner life full peace, happiness, and well-being.

This ancient discipline has been practiced by all the great spiritual leaders, as well as the majority of the brightest minds in history; Jesus, The Buddha, Lao Tzu, Da Vinci, Isaac Newton, Nicola Tesla, Sr. Carl Gustav Jung, etc.  The Discipline of Meditation brings about inspiration and creative imagination, two fundamental aspects that all geniuses share. 

Come join us to learn about the science behind Meditation, as well as the positive spiritual and personal benefits of this transcendental Discipline. 

"Man perfects himself to the extent that he is able to feel the truth." Dr. Arnold Krumm-Heller, a great mystic and physician of the previous century.

Topics of discussion:

- Meditation; psychological, spiritual, and health benefits. 

- Mindfulness

- Transcendental ethics.

- Guided meditation session

***Doors open at 3:45 and close at 5pm!*****

NOTE: PLEASE ONLY RSVP IF ARE ALSO ABLE TO ATTEND A VOLUNTEER ORIENTATION AT THE APOLLO THEATER ON FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 18TH FROM 6PM - 8PM & YOU DEFINITELY KNOW YOU'RE AVAILABLE TO HELP FOR THE REQUESTED TIME BLOCK (4PM - 8PM) ON SEPTEMBER 19TH.


The Apollo Theater is hosting it's 3rd Annual community initiative focused on family health and wellness - Harlem Healthy Soul Festival. Sponsored by Coca-Cola, Harlem Healthy Soul Festival is designed to serve as a platform for Harlem families to learn about the numerous community health resources to live active and healthy lives.


This day long, free event will take place on Saturday, September 19th beginning at noon and will transform 126th Street behind the Apollo, into a block party filled with music, entertainment, celebrity performances, health and educational resources and family fun. Families are encouraged to participate in an array of activities such as health screenings, nutrition-focused cooking demonstrations, celebrity performances, and exercise modules. EmblemHealth and Manhattan’s Physician Group will also provide free health screenings.

For more information about the festival, performances, & celebrity updates, please visit www.harlemhealthy.com.

Our Meetup
In this unique community service opportunity, 10 volunteers from 4pm to 8pm will be assisting the Apollo Theater event organizers with operational duties of the festival, which will include troubleshooting and aiding the festival vendors, escorting talent to and from the green room area to the stage and general duties that may come with an event of this nature. <a>HarlemGo side note:</a> This also is an EXCELLENT TIME to do some professional networking as well!

PLEASE ONLY RSVP IF ARE ALSO ABLE TO ATTEND A VOLUNTEER ORIENTATION AT THE APOLLO THEATER ON FRIDAY, SEPTEMBER 18TH FROM 6PM - 8PM & YOU DEFINITELY KNOW YOU'RE AVAILABLE TO HELP FOR THE REQUESTED TIME BLOCK (4PM - 8PM) ON SEPTEMBER 19TH.

<a>Please read:</a>


The day of the festival, please try to arrive for sign-in 15 minutes prior to the start of your commitment (3:45pm). Please only RSVP if you know you are able to help for the entire time from 4pm - 8pm. Volunteers should be energetic and comfortable working/walking in outdoor conditions (rain or shine). Wear comfortable clothing & shoes. 

Lunch will be provided, and each volunteer will receive a festival T-shirt.

That's pretty much it. If there are any questions, feel free to post them in the comments/notifications section below or give Daniel a call/text at[masked] if you're running late, need directions, can't find the group, etc. Thanks!

results.description:
Hi everyone!

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up. Also, please bring a white t-shirt, a red t-shirt, lots of water and be ready to have fun!

We also created a map of the field location since it can be tricky to find: Field Location Map.


If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!


Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

No ball hogging

The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:Field F in Central Park  can be accessed from west 97th street or east 97th street on either side Central Park. We also created a map of the field location since it can be tricky to find: Field Location Map

Directions: By train: From the West side take the B or C to 96th street stop. From the east side take the 6 train to 96th street stop St.

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals: If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee: Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring: A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. Please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds: If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for a future game. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List: If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will receive an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has openned up:). Please RSVP as soon as you get that e-mail since everyone on the waiting list will get the same e-mail. The first person who RSVP's takes the spot! Also check our Calendar for other games

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Join other writers for an hour of focused writing!

4:00 - Show up early, stake out a spot and either socialize or get a jump on writing.
4:30 - Start. Introductions, and we'll share what we're working on.
4:35 - Get down to business. An hour of silence and solid writing!
5:35- Brief follow up. People are encouraged to share experiences & ideas, network or take off as they like.

If you're spending too much time THINKING about writing, come and join us for a session of focused writing. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice.

WHERE: Milk and Honey Cafe located at 1119 Newkirk Ave. The closest train station is Newkirk Plaza on the Q line. Walk 3 block down Newkirk Avenue until you reach Westminster Road. We are sitting at the table in the back.

SOME TIPS:

Laptops are welcome. Remember to charge your laptop ahead of time.

Please buy something to support this organic cafe. It would make the owner smile.

Come on time! If you come late, we will have already started.
Bring headphones if you don't want outside noise distraction.

RSVP only if you can make it, and update as soon as possible if your plans change.

You will see progress in your writing project by spending the minimum of a single hour per week on it. This is your practice/focus time, so I hope to see you there.

Don't know where to begin, read this.

http://gaiateabrew.com/leonbell/wp-content/uploads/2014/03/Mini-Guide-to-Writing.pdf

results.description:
ATTENTION: Due to high projected "Real Feel" temperatures for Saturday, the time of this tour has been shifted back into Twilight, with a meeting time of 4:45 pm. All other information is unchanged. 

Here's a repeat performance of the brand-new tour of the season as we return to daytime hours!

Let’s say right out: Nope, we don’t have the keys to get inside the park, but there’s so much to say about the extraordinary people that have lived along it over the years, that you won’t miss that one bit!

The only private park in Manhattan, Gramercy Park was conceived as an exclusive enclave for the elite of the city, particularly in the mid to end of the 19th century. These four small blocks forming the park’s perimeter have held much more than their share of movers and shakers. We’ll hear from perennial diarist George Templeton Strong, and about Peter Cooper, Edwin Booth, and Thomas Edison, just to name a few.  And throughout it all, there are flashes of the genius of the tragically flawed architect Stanford White. Stroll back in time with us to visit mayors and governors, book publishers and inventors, philanthropists and alleged murderesses. It may seem tranquil here, but what stories there are to tell.

Where to meet: Meet in the front of the Gramercy Park Hotel, at 2 Lexington Avenue, between East 21 and 22 streets. Take the 6 or N/R trains to their respective "23 Street" stations.

When to meet: 4:45pm for a 5pm start. I will be holding a sign that says "Gramercy Park". There are restroom facilities inside the Gramercy Park Hotel; please be sure to take a visit there if necessary before the tour starts.

Fee: $20 cash, $15 for seniors 65 + with proof of age; exact change appreciated! Please bring bills, not coins. Sorry, please do not bring dogs or minor children age 17 or below on the tours.

The tour is 2.5 hours long.  For sunny days, be sure to bring a hat and a bottle of water. Check the weather reports on the day of the tour; if there is a chance of rain, please bring your own umbrella.  While Friendly Native tours usually do take place on the date and at the time they are scheduled, on occasion they will be postponed in cases of high temperatures or high probability of rain,  and an email sent out to that effect to all who have registered for the event.
results.how_to_find_us: I'll be holding a sign reading GRAMERCY PARK
results.name: Encore:  TALES of GRAMERCY PARK!

results.description:
A Conversation About Happiness

Alternating Hosts: George & Michael Y

</a> CitiCorp Atrium Lower Level
153 E 53rd street (Between Lexington and 3rd ave)

From 5:00pm-7:30pm (it's okay to arrive late or leave early.). Look for our red Meetup Sign.

Get ready to get happier simply by talking about happiness! The theory behind these events comes from a classic psychology study showing that by simply talking regularly about happiness we can become much happier.

While we'll depart from them however much we may wish, like by talking about gratitude, acts of kindness, meditation and other happiness techniques, the following list of 14 topics will serve as a backdrop for our discussions.

1. Keep busy and be more active
2. Spend more time socializing
3. Be productive at meaningful work
4. Get better organized and plan things out
5. Stop worrying
6. Lower your expectations and aspirations
7. Develop positive, optimistic thinking
8. Become present oriented
9. Develop an outgoing, social personality
10. Work on a healthy personality
11. Be yourself
12. Eliminate negative feelings and problems
13. Close relationships are the number one source of happiness
14. Put happiness as your most important priority.

Here's some background on the research our group is based on.

In 1980 three New Zealand researchers found that after eight 2-hour conversation sessions about happiness over four weeks, their subjects reported a 22 percent increase in their happiness. Continuing their twice-weekly sessions, by the sixteenth week they reported being 42 percent happier.

Our list of topics comes from Fort Myers, Florida psychologist Michael Fordyce's "14 Fundamentals of Happiness." In 1977, Fordyce pioneered the science of happiness-increase with the world's first experiment designed to boost individual happiness.

That's the group. It's important that our events be fun! So with that in mind, let's get serious about ramping up our enjoyment of life!

At the NE corner of 53rd and Lex., walk down wide steps (see photo) leading to lower outdoor patio. Pass entrance to the subway station on the right, and walk through the revolving door. Walk straight about 30 yards, down a few steps; the Atrium is on the left.

Resources:

For those interested in learning about the major findings from social science research about happiness, and becoming happier, here are links to several excellent peer-reviewed articles that can be downloaded as pdf files for free. (Note: Although these classic articles are somewhat dated, decades of research on happiness reveal that findings on happiness tend to be extremely stable over time.)

<a href="http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.335.9655&rep=rep1&type=pdf">Pursuing Happiness: The Architecture of Sustainable Change
By S Lyubomirsky, KM Sheldon and D Schkade, 2005.  21 pages

In Pursuit of Happiness: Empirical Answers to Philosophical Questions
By P Kesebir and E Diener, 2008. 9 pages.

Subjective Well-Being: Three Decades of Progress
By E Diener, EM Suh, RE Lucas and HL Smith, 1999. 27 pages

results.name: A Conversation About Happiness, Citicorp at 53rd and Lex.

results.description:
The new format lives on: 50/50 Co-Ed Games. We'll open up 12 spots for men and 12 spots for women. And each team will have at least 2 women playing on the court at all times.

Sign up here if you're a dude.

Other than that, the idea will be basically the same:

We rent out the gym from 5:00-8:00pm. 

Please arrive at least 5-10 minutes early as the sooner everyone arrives, the sooner we can begin playing. Note that all games stop at 7:45pm as we have to be out of the gym by 8:00pm. (If you get there late, please only ring the bell once. It is very loud! And it takes us a few minutes to get downstairs.) The gym is on the 10th fl. & has adjoining bathrooms, lockers, and water fountains.

We'll hit up McSwiggans (393 2nd Avenue @ 23rd St) later! 

Don't forget:

* You must be no more than 5'8" to play!

* You must RSVP on the site in order to attend!

* You will be asked to sign a waiver for 2014 as we're not a litigious group. 

If you have any problems with the prepay, just shoot one of the organizers an email.

Here are the basic rules we follow for games:

1. Play by ones and twos to 11 - win by one point.

2. Make it - take it.

3. Backcourt if the ball hits the rim or backboard. Air balls are fair game to put right back up.

4. Jump balls/disputed calls will be determined by a three pointer since the laws of basketball physics are very clear that "the ball never lies."

5. Walls, half-court line, and ceiling are out of bounds.  

6. Subs will enter the game no later than 6 points in (once one of the teams reaches 6 points). The sub will start the following game. Teams will regulate themselves but let's make sure everyone plays.

See you on the court! B-)

***NOTE***

In an effort for us to reduce overcrowding and to maintain a more accurate estimate of how many people to expect, please sign up online if you intend to play. There is a waiting list if all spots have been taken. We ask that you please just do not show up unannounced as you will kindly be asked to turned away. 

Also feel free to bring your own basketball for shoot-around. And don't forget to clip your nails prior to game day. We tried playing with Edward Scissorhands once - it didn't turn out so well.


*****NEW*****

Share your Spotify playlists and tracks with us and we'll play them during gametime!

Send an email to [masked]

And please submit good tunes otherwise we'll be Basketball for the Musically Challenged...
results.name: 50/50 Full Co-Ed Game: CO-ED SIGN UP

It has been five years of amazing craftiness and lots of sipping and it is time to celebrate the talented group of crafters that we are. Join in on the festivities at Tanner Smith's. We have reserved the back room and will be dining and sipping cocktails (and pints). Bring a project, have some food and drinks whilst chatting it up with NYCs finest knitters, crocheters and other craftologists. 

There will be a couple raffles and some prizes that include PnP swag. This just in! PnP Tote Bags stuffed with goodies that will be raffled off. A couple of items in the bags are gift cards that were donated from Knitty City and La Casita. Oh yes they did! We also have some great door prizes and other gifts made by fellow PnPers for a drawing. 

Tanner Smith's is located on 55th Street (Between 7th Ave & Broadway) in Manhattan. Nearest Subways are the N/Q/R or the B/D/E or F. 

$20 cover (Includes one beverage and the cocktails at Tanner's look crafty!)

Feel free to bring a friend or significant other that enjoys the finer things in life, like a good pint or a nice worsted weight or is supportive of your stash or needs to be inspired by some fellow artisans to pick up a craft (beer).

Also, cocktail party attire is not required, but Amy is going to try to clean up and look nice for this one. So wear what you like and feel comfortable in, and know that some people may get their fancy on.

results.description:
PICK-UP CO-ED SOCCER GAMES @ CHELSEA PARK  

                                     Check our Facebook page:

          facebook.com/ManhattanInternationalCoedSoccer


                                NO CLEATS OR STUDS ALLOWED

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cR_TuiCA8RM

GAME DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for all levels and people that prefer to play a non-competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

Game Format:

We'll play three simultaneous games of 8 on 8, with small goals. There will be 6 teams on the field and we will play THREE games, 30 minutes/game. Every 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play against different team. Please check our meetup message board on Friday night or before 12.00 pm on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

No power shots allowed. No power shots means; you can shoot the ball but not as hard as you can. This doesn't mean that you can not take the shot at all. Kicking the ball or taking the shot on the goal, is of course allowed.

***If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.***

If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game and maybe a two game ban.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Location:

CHELSEA PARK.

Between 27th and 28th street and 10th Avenue.

Take A, C or E to 23rd St and 8th Ave and walk to 10th Ave and 27th St or any subway line to 34th St and Penn Station and walk for about 8 minutes to 28th St and 10th Ave.

What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.25 when you RSVP. This $9.25 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:

Refunds will be issued if the RSVP is changed by Wednesday before 12.00PM or if the game is cancelled. The game can be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe like heavy rain, snow or thunder.

After the game we'll go to Molly Wee for a pint or two:

                             Molly Wee Restaurant

                                       402 8th Ave, 

                                 New York, NY 10001

                                    (212)[masked]

                            PLEASE CHECK THEIR MENU!

                                      themollywee.com

PARTICIPATING IN MANHATTAN-INTERNATIONAL-COED-SOCCER ACTIVITIES AGREEMENT:

I certify that I have no known medical or other conditions that could interfere with my participation in Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer activities. I also understand and accept that the practice of soccer, both indoor and outdoor, involves certain risks of physical injury. Therefore, I, individually, hereby release and discharge, Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and Assistant Organizers from any and all claims, actions, damages, losses, liabilities, costs and expenses of any kind whatsoever, including but not limited to any claims of negligence, arising out of, resulting from, by reason of, or in connection with my participation in any of Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer programs or activities. Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer Organizer and its Assistant Organizers reserve the right to take and utilize photographs, video, or any type of recording of participating person while engaged in our or associated activities. I consent to Manhattan-International-COED-Soccer use the photograph, video, or recording of me, for advertising, promotional, or related purposes, and waive all rights to compensation and other rights which may arise as a result.

results.description:
We'll be gathering this month at my flat on Madison between 110th and 111th. Best way to get here is either the 6 or the 2/3 to 110th St.

I made the start time a bit earlier than usual because we'll be watching Stanley Kubrick's excellent adaptation of the novel, so I thought we'd begin at 5 so the evening doesn't run too late. Feel free to bring stuff to eat/drink, though I will naturally provide some (no barbecue this time, though).

About the book:
A vicious fifteen-year-old droog is the central character of this 1963 classic. In Anthony Burgess's nightmare vision of the future, where the criminals take over after dark, the story is told by the central character, Alex, who talks in a brutal invented slang that brilliantly renders his and his friends' social pathology. A Clockwork Orange is a frightening fable about good and evil, and the meaning of human freedom. When the state undertakes to reform Alex to "redeem" him, the novel asks, "At what cost?" This edition includes the controversial last chapter not published in the first edition and Burgess's introduction "A Clockwork Orange Resucked.”

About the whisky:
The smooth, oak flavor blends well with the barrel proof. Selected from barrels in the heart of our Kentucky warehouse, it has remained untouched for 15 years and unhurried by time. “A whiskey connoisseur’s bonanza,…remarkable find…ranks with the best whiskeys,” Paul Pacult’s Spirit Journal.
results.name: A Clockwork Orange +  Pappy Van Winkle/"Moloko"

results.description:
How to be unconditionally happy?

A mind that is calm, without anticipation and agitation is the birth right of all individuals. A mind that is in the present moment will be happy.


What can get you to that state?

The rest you gain by reposing in yourself is deeper than the deepest sleep. The deeper your rest, the more dynamic your activity is. By being peaceful and happy you can turn your body into a power-house by generating an inner source of energy.


Meditation is simple and is a practical way to recharge and rejuvenate; empowering you to do more of the things you love.

Come join us for free guided session and experience the power of meditation.


Workshop Contents:

- Understanding the nature of the mind!
- Relaxing Breathing Techniques
- Guided Meditation
- Introduction to the Happiness Course and Sudarshan Kriya
