results.description:
On Sunday we are going to the North-South Lake Campground in Catskills. It is time to hike and run on some real mountains!


I can pick you up in NYC and we'll carpool all together in our RawMobile. As you can see, the number of spots is very limited, so first come first serve. The details about pick up and drop off are below. To reserve a spot just RSVP to this meetup.


Our recent day trips to the Catskills were awesome, so we're doing it again. Some folks were running, some were hiking, but all had fun and made new friends. Check out our photos and comments from the past trips.


There are lots of ways to enjoy a day at North-South Lake Campground, but the main point of interest to us is probably the famous Escarpment Trail. If you have never heard of this trail, take a look here: http://escarpmenttrail.com/ This is one of the most beautiful places for hiking and trail running in New York state.

Here is a video from the 2013 Escarpment  Trail race:

https://vimeo.com/71310538

Please note that we are not doing the entire trail (if you really want to do all 19 miles, let me know and we'll figure out how to set it up). Also, if you're interested on doing this trip on Sunday, let me know. 

I  will get you there and back and will take care of the day pass to the campground, and also we'll have lots of fruit and bottled water for everyone. We'll also have few picnic/beach  blankets. 

We will start hiking/running at North-South lake campground. I suggest doing about 5 miles of the trail (to the crashed airplane, or maybe a bit further), and then turning around. I will be staying at the back of the group, and faster hikers/runners can go ahead of us if they want to.


The beauty of this plan is that it's impossible to get lost. The trail is VERY EASY TO FOLLOW (it is well-marked with blue markers) so you can go at your own pace and turn around when you feel like it. Just be sure to get back on time before we leave (5pm sharp).


You are welcome to hike with anyone else in the group, but all abilities are welcome and everyone can enjoy this trail at their own pace.  The trail is rugged and at times very steep. Please prepare accordingly. There is no any water on the trail, so be sure to have enough with you. On weekends there are lots of people hiking there, so we certainly won't be alone there.

Other activities that you might choose to enjoy during our trip to the campground:


- hiking around the lake,


- visiting scenic spot of Mountain House,


- renting a boat (availability might be limited),


- lake swimming (in the designated area),


- suntanning and enjoying the beach.

More information about the campground is here: http://www.dec.ny.gov/outdoor/24487.html


Map of the campground is here: http://www.dec.ny.gov/docs/permits_ej_operations_pdf/northsouthlake2015.pdf

There are nice showers and bathrooms right by the beach (which is also our parking area and starting/finishing point of the hike/run). There are also picnic areas with tables and benches all around the beach.



What to bring (optional):

Towel, clean clothes, flip-flops, gels, your favorite snack, map, insects repellent, rain jacket.


You will be able to leave your extra stuff in the car if needed.


Pick up/Drop off:

The main point of the pick up is bus station by GW Bridge (at 8 am sharp!). To get there you can take A train (to 175th street). 


The drive takes just over 2 hours, we'll leave NYC at 8am, get to the lake shortly after 10am, run, eat, enjoy the beach, and head out back to the city by 5pm. We'll be back in NYC shortly after 7pm.

If you don't need a ride, then just come over to the campground and meet us there, no need to RSVP here.


Bad weather cancels the trip! Please check this meetup for the updates a day before.

Cell reception: T-mobile doesn't work there. AT&T mostly does work. Not sure about the others.


Time to go to the mountains!

Legal Disclaimer

results.description:
Run the Newport half marathon, the most beautiful course in the Tri-State; right here in our own Jersey City. This race is a perfect half marathon for everyone, new runners and for runners training for Fall marathons this is at the right time of their training.

http://www.newporthalfmarathon.com/

Registration usually is from 6:30 to 8:15 am in Newport Town Square, 100 Town Square Place, Jersey City. After picking the packet; lets meet outside Starbucks (facing the waterfront) at 8 or earlier. We can stretch or discuss the race or anything. And get together for some group pictures at 8:05.

Price: $47.00 Race Fee + $3.00 SignUp Fee +

Price increases to $50.00 after August 13, 2015 @ 11:59pm EDT.

For those who have not run the race before, this is a Flat, fast, USATF certified course, includes breathtaking views of the Statue of Liberty, Ellis Island, the Verrazano Narrows Bridge and the NYC skyline.

Water and energy drink stations. Clocks at every mile.

AND there is a strong finish line magnet to reel you in smoothly. As we say, its a home race in our backyard, we are JCRunners and we run it consistent and relaxed!.

Refreshments -- there is always plenty of food to fill you up afterwards. Its a well organized race with bag pickup.

Stick around after the race for the Ceremony & Random Prize Drawing at 11 am, there may be more than 10% + chances you will get something, lot of us have got something!

results.description:
Flag Football Game at Cunningham Park (196th St and Union Turnpike) in Queens. Come out and join us!

We have cones and flags so all you need is cleats if that is what you prefer. GAMES WILL ALWAYS BE PLAYED REGARDLESS OF THE WEATHER CONDITIONS i.e. rain, snow, cold, mud, ice, storm, hurricane, etc...we never cancel games due to weather...games are fun and competitive, all skill levels are welcome, please contact me if you have any questions.

NOTE: PLEASE RSVP "YES" ONLY IF YOU ARE GOING TO SHOW UP TO THE GAME.  YOU CAN CHANGE YOUR RSVP IF SOMETHING COMES UP (OR IF YOU DON'T WANT TO PLAY IF IT'S TOO COLD/IT'S RAINING/IT'S SNOWING) AND YOU CAN'T MAKE IT.  NO-SHOWS WILL BE REMOVE FROM THE GROUP.  IT IS IMPORTANT TO HAVE AN ACCURATE HEAD COUNT SO WE KNOW HOW MANY PEOPLE ARE REALLY COMING.

ere are some of the new changes we have made and a reminder of some of the guidelines we already have:

1) You can not add  guests to your RSVP.  Anyone is free to come and play IF AND ONLY IF you have a profile in meetup and have joined our group.  It's 100% FREE to join and it only takes about 2 minutes to sign up and RSVP.  There are also FREE mobile apps for iPhones and Android phones so you can RSVP easily on the go.  If any of your friends has been playing and wants to continue to play, ask them to go to http://www.meetup.com/Cunningham-Park-Football/ and sign up and RSVP individually.  YOU CAN NOT PLAY if you're not signed up and RSVPd.

2) The first 20 people that RSVP for the game, will play a 9-on-9 game with 1 sub.  Everyone on the waiting list will pick players and play against the winner of the game.  Games will be to 2 scores.  If a team gets 2 scores, with the score 2-1, the other team gets one (1) more possession to try to score and tie the game.  If the game is tied again, the game is now to 3 points and the same rule applies, once one of the teams gets score #3, the other team gets just one (1) more possession to try to tie the game.  If 20 or less players show up to the game, game can be played to whatever score everyone agrees to.

3) If you're one of the first 20 to RSVP, but you're late, the next person on the waiting list that's present on the field will take your place and play in the first game.

4) On a safety, ball stays at the goal line and the next down will be played.  For example: If a 2nd down play is ran and a safety occurs, the ball stays at the goal line and the 3rd down will be played.

5) On an OBVIOUS "Defensive Pass interference", the ball will stay at the line of scrimmage but you reset your plays and start at 1st down again.  For example: If a 3rd down play is ran and a DPI occurs, the ball stays at the line of scrimmage and a 1st down will be played, then 2nd, then 3rd...etc.

6) On an OBVIOUS "Offensive Pass interference", the ball stays at the line of scrimmage and the offensive time will lose a down.  For example: If a 2nd down play is ran and an OPI occurs, the offensive team will now be on a 4th down situation from the line of scrimmage.

7) As you might have noticed we have had very few injuries (knock on wood) throughout the years.  This is why we wanted to remind you of the following:

-Stiff arming, flag guarding and hand slapping are NOT ALLOWED.

-Blocks from the back are NOT allowed ad they're obviously dangerous and can cause injuries.

-VERY IMPORTANT: If you are the offensive player and have the ball in your hands, you MUST avoid contact and CAN NOT under any circumstances lower your shoulders and try to initiate contact with an defensive player.  This is flag football, if you're looking for a different type of game there are plenty of other places and leagues to play flag or full-contact football.

8) Donations:  I pay the monthly fee for hosting these meetups and never charge anyone.  All we asked for you is to drop at least $1 in the container we have set up for this, all the money is used for equipment, flags, cones, etc.  You can click on "Group Tools > Money" and see where all the money is going.  If we buy anything with that money we record the transaction and upload a picture of the receipt of whatever equipment we bought.  Next thing we want to get are end zone weighted pylons and we want to buy orange rope so we can mark the field faster and more accurately to avoid any arguments about where the first down is or what not.

IMPORTANT: WE ARE ALL ADULTS AND OBVIOUSLY CAN'T FORCE ANYONE TO DO ANYTHING.  WE NEED EVERYONE'S COOPERATION TO FOLLOW THESE SIMPLE GUIDELINES TO KEEP THE GAME FUN AND COMPETITIVE.  IF FOR ANY REASON YOU DISAGREE OR BELIEVE THAT THESE GUIDELINES DO NOT FIT YOUR STYLE OF PLAY OR WHAT YOU'RE LOOKING FOR ON A PICK-UP GAME, YOU'RE WELCOME TO PLAY WITH A DIFFERENT MEETUP GROUP OR IN ANY OTHER PICK-UP GAME...NO HARD FEELINGS.

If you have any suggestions, questions or concerns, please feel free to reach me at[masked] or [masked]

Regards,

Carlos

results.description:
Will Juventus finally snag a win in the[masked] Serie A campaign?  Join us bright and early on Sunday morning at The Football Factory to find out.  A rare morning game - take advantage and get your brunch and coffee on while catching Genoa vs Juve at 9:00AM.  The team need this win to recover the unexpected losses and draw from the first three matches.  But how about that spectacular Champions League win over Man City?!!

Thanks to all new members who have been joining us.  I've been based overseas for the past year plus and have been organizing these meetups from Italy/Canada and other locales.  I am still looking for someone to volunteer to assist with organizing/hosting.  If you're interested please send me a message on here or on our Facebook page:  www.facebook.com/JuventiNYC . I was just in NYC for two weeks but no Serie A matches were happening while I was there - it would have been great to see everyone.

Please RSVP if you're planning to attend.  It helps the bar to know how much space to reserve and also for everyone to find each other.  Sporting your black & white stripes is recommended!  If it's your first time visiting the Football Factory, to find our group, take an immediate left after you walk in Legends and go downstairs..veer to the right on the staircase as the Juve matches are normally shown on the bank of TVs along the right wall after you go downstairs.

Enjoy the game and as always..fino alla fine e forza Juventus!

results.description:
Sunday Brunch/Jamaican Style!!– Sept. 20th
Talking about variety, this ride has it all. There will be two routes and a menu that will spice up your taste buds. Let’s start with the routes which are both very nice and scenic. The advanced route (Group A) takes you around the Jamaica Bay, but at a intermediate pace of 17-20mph. Group B will take a shorter route to Riis Beach/Belle Harbor and ride at a more comfortable pace.
After working up a hardy appetite we’ll finish our rides in Coney Island for a rewarding and delightful Jamaican Style brunch at Footprints (see menu below)….YUMMY!!! Here are the details:
Sunday, Sept. 20th — Sunday Brunch/Jamaican Style
Starting @ Prospect Park (Parkside & Ocean)
Time: 8:30 on the pedals 8:45ish
Distances: 35 miles group “A” and 22 miles for group “B”
Terrain: All flat
Fee: $10 for guidance & support Brunch is from 11:30-3:pm, cost $20 and it’s worth every penny. The hope is to get us there before 12:noon, cause it first come first sitting. Of course brunch is optional. There are a number of trains (Q, D, F, N) for you to use to return home or you can ride if you are not too stuffed. Please RSVP to me at [masked] if planing to attend.
results.name: Sunday Brunch Ride/Jamaican Style!!'

results.description:
For summer we have a single 10:00 am Sunday contemporary worship service popular with young families Children are welcome.  Free temporary parking passes available from any usher.


The Church-in-the-Gardens is an exciting, stimulating, and challenging place to grow your faith. We invite “seekers” new to exploring faithful living, dedicated followers of Christ, people filled with a new enthusiasm and a desire to serve and grow, people who’ve “fallen away” from “organized religion” but are giving it a second look, and everyone else in-between, to join us! We need, and welcome, everyone’s gift. There is a place for you in our fellowship. A spirit of inclusion, and sharing, abound in our congregation.

results.description:
NEW YORK TRI/DUATHLON SERIES
in memory of Ned Northrop

Lake Welch, Harriman State Park, NY
(30 miles north of NY City)

Sunday, September 20, 2015
Race Start - 9:00 am

Triathlon - Swim - 0.25 mi. Bike - 12 mi. Run - 2 mi.
Duathlon - Run - 2 mi. Bike -12 mi. Run - 2 mi.
Rain or Shine! No rain date! Race Map: Click Here

Like us on facebook.com/NYTRI for event updates and photos from prior years.

COMPETITOR INFO

FIELD: First 600 entries (triathlon + duathlon combined).
* No relay teams

NEW YORK TRIATHLON - NYTRI has staged over 600 multi-sport events since 1984 and is proud to claim the best safety record in the country. The following rules and regulations are designed for your personal safety and enjoyment. Failure to comply with these rules will result in penalties and/or disqualification.

ABSOLUTELY NO PARTS OF ENTRY FEES WILL BE REFUNDED, TRANSFERRED, SUBSTITUTED OR CREDITED. IMPORTANT:
Race packets will not be issued without your knowing your race bib number and presenting photo ID!
You will receive an email with you race bib number approximately 3-4 days before the event. At check-in you must know your bib number before getting in to the line that corresponds to your bib number.
If you do not receive your email and do not know your bib number, you may look it up on an alphabetical entrants list posted near the registration tables before getting in line for packet pick up.
There will be a label attached to your bib number that has all your personal and race information. Please check it for accuracy and notify registration officials immediately if you find discrepancies.

XPRESS CHECK IN: NYTRI members should proceed directly to the Xpress Check in line. You must have a valid NYTRI 2015 membership card and know your race/bib number to receive your race packet.

ENTRY FEES:
Before April 20 Triathlon - $80 Duathlon - $60
April 21 - August 20 Triathlon - $90 Duathlon - $70
August 21 - Sept. 19 Triathlon - $100 Duathlon - $80
Race Day: Triathlon - $110 Duathlon - $90
* No T-shirts to race day entries.
* No credit cards or personal checks accepted on race day.
- NYTRI Member Discount:: Triathlon: $10 Duathlon - $5 AWARDS:
Triathlon: 1st, 2nd, 3rd overall male/female and in 5-year groups; 18-24, 25-29, 30-34, 35-39, 40-44, 45-49, 50-54, 55-59, 60+ female, 60-64, 65-69, 70+ male.
Duathlon: 1st, 2nd, 3rd overall male/female and in 10-year age groups; 18-29, 30-39, 40-49, 50-59, 60+ female, 60-69, 70+ male .
* To receive an award you must be present at the awards ceremony - Race management has authority to change racecourse and format, check-in and start times.
- No entrants under 18 years of age. SCHEDULE OF EVENTS:
Sunday (Race Day) - Lake Welch, Harriman State Park.
7:15 - 8:30 am - Check-in. new entries, packet pick-up.
*** No Numbers issued or race packets saved after 8:30 am ***
8:45 a.m. - Course orientation, final race instructions
9:00 a.m. - Race Start (rain or shine).
11:00 a.m. - Course closes, Awards presentation.

Park Notice: Dogs (on or off leash) will not be allowed in to Lake Welch Beach at Harriman State Park.

VOLUNTEERS:
Is there someone you know who can volunteer while your competing? Just call NYT at[masked] from 10:00-5:00 and leave a message with their name and confirm that they will be coming to the race. Volunteers will receive a souvenir T-shirt and our sincere thanks! TRANSITION AREA:
Entry to competitors with race numbers ONLY!. Please request family members and friends not to accompany you in the transition area. Bicycles must be placed on assigned bike racks. Bikes on wrong racks will be removed from the race. NO cycling in or out of the transition area. Cycling past the "DISMOUNT" signs at the entrance to the transition area will result in a 2 minute penalty.

SWIM (Triathlon):
The swim will be in waves of 100 competitors per wave. Wave #1 is for competitors 1 - 100, wave #2 is for 101 - 200, wave #3 is 201 - 300, etc.
The time between each wave will be 2 minutes.

Maximum time allowed for the 1/4 mile swim is 15 minutes. If you take longer than 30 minutes to complete the swim you will not be allowed to continue the remainder of the race. Competitors must wear the official swim cap provided at check-in. Failure to wear the official swim cap will result in DISQUALIFICATION! Upon completion of the swim, you will run 100 yards from the beach to the transition area. You must notify a race official IMMEDIATELY if you do not complete the swim. Failure to do so will DISQUALIFY you from participating in any future events organized by the NYT. Wet suits are allowed. Water temperature in past 20 years has been between 70 - 74 degrees.

Due to Parks lifeguard restrictions, competitors are NOT allowed in the water PRIOR to or AFTER the Triathlon.

RUN COURSE: (Triathlon & Duiathlon): The run course of 2.4 miles is clearly marked, and takes place entirely on paved roads within the area of Lake Welch..

Duathletes: The second run is identical to the first.

BIKE COURSE: (Triathlon & Duathlon)
Exit the transition are and proceed along the perimeter of the parking lot to the entrance to Lake Welch. Make a left turn and circle back to Lake Welch Drive and continue to Lake Sebago/Seven Lakes Drive.

Make a right at the bottom of the hill where Lake Welch Drive ends at Seven Lakes Drive. Use caution as you will be biking downhill at high speed and you must make a 90 degree turn to stay on course. Continue on Seven Lakes Drive. Go completely around Kanawakee Circle and return totransition area at Lake Welch.

It is your responsibility to know and stay on the course at all times. If you are uncertain of the course, review the course map BEFORE the race and follow the guidelines of the CONE DIRECTIONAL SYSTEM below.

CONE DIRECTIONAL SYSTEM: All turns on the bike course are marked by a series of small (12") orange cones. Following them is essential to stay on course. If in doubt at any intersection, always follow the direction marked by the orange cones. Exit all traffic circles in the direction of the cones. Do not expect volunteers, marshalls and/or police personnel to point you in the right direction. They are on the course only for traffic control at key intersections.

PLEASE DISCARD WATER CUPS IN THE GARBAGE CANS LOCATED JUST PAST THE WATER TABLES. DO NOT THROW WATER CUPS ON THE ROAD OR IN THE PARKING LOT!

DRAFTING RULES: You must maintain a distance of three bike lengths from the bike in front of you! You may not be closer than this distance for any period exceeding 15 seconds. If you are, you will be assessed a TWO minute penalty for each successive violation. Riding alongside another biker will also result in a two minute penalty.

Pack Riding is a Serious Violation of the Rules of Tri/Biathlon! You can file an official complaint regarding "drafters" by noting their race number. A competitor who has three "drafting reports" filed against him/her will automatically receive a penalty for each infraction.

POST-RACE: Award winners must be present at the post-race awards ceremony to claim their prize. No Exceptions! Refreshments are for competitors ONLY and are not provided for friends and family members.

===========================================================
RACE NUMBERS/ELECTRONIC TIMING:
On the morning of the race, you will pick up an electronic timing chip that corresponds to your assigned bib number. This chip must be attached with the supplied velcro strap to your ankle.and must remain attached throughout the entire event.
After you finish the event, you must remove the chip and drop it in the collection bin at the end of the timing chute.
If you lose your chip during the race or fail to turn it in after you cross the finish line, you will be charged $105..
Your bib number must be attached to the FRONT of your shirt (or race belt) during the entire race .
If you enter the transition area or cross the finish line and your number is not clearly visible on your FRONT, you will be receive a 2 minute penalty.
The 2-sided vinyl (adhesive-backed) bike frame number must be attached to the front of the top tube of your bicycle and may not be removed until you leave the leave the transition area.
Check the label affixed to the timing tag (on the front of your bib number) for correct information regarding your name, age, sex and category (T-Triathlon, D-Duathlon).
Notify officials prior to the race of any mistakes! ==========================================

RESULTS:
Results will be posted on our web site www.nytri.org.
For immdeiate notification and for photos of the event LIKE us on facebook.com/NYTri. DIRECTIONS:
From Palisades Parkway/Geo. Washington Bridge: Take upper level of GW Bridge, stay to extreme right and get on to Palisades Parkway. Take Palisades Parkway to exit 16. Follow signs to Lake Welch. Approximately 2 miles.

Registration: http://nytc.org/calender.cfm

results.description:
ODSC is proud to announce the Boston Data Feastival 2015 Livestream! Join the fun and pop in if you can. View the list of livestream speakers and workshop presenters below.

*RSVP and we will email you the livestream links*

For more info, please visit: http://www.bostondatafest.com/

Schedule (all times EST):
9/20 - IoT Day (Track 1)

9:00 - 10:30 “Is the IoT Wasted on the Young? [Workshop]“
Erich Jacobs, ONKOL

10:30 - 12:00 “There is no IoT Stack [Workshop]“
Tom Luczak, Flowthings.io

13:00 - 13:45 “Privacy in the Ubiquitous Information Environment: What Every Data Scientist Needs to Know”
Deborah Hurley, Fellow IQSS, Harvard University

13:45 - 14:30 “Visions from the Internet of Things”
Chad Jones, Deep Information Sciences

14:30 - 15:15 “Advanced Data Analytics in IoT Applications: Concepts, Challenges, and Tools”
Yan Zhang, Microsoft

15:15 - 16:00 “Putting my blood metrics in context”
Gil Blander, InsideTracker

16:00 - 16:30 “Preparing your organization for the Internet of Things”
Kris Alexander, Akamai Technologies

16:30 - 17:00 “Defining the Internet of Things”
Thomas Lesser, Big Ass Solutions


9/19 - IoT Day (Track 2)

9:00 - 10:30 “Challenges of IoT Value Proposition – “It’s not Big Data” [Workshop]“
Nauman Sheikh, ASRYM

10:30 - 12:00 “Coding to enable the Tactile Internet (a.k.a. dynamic, resilient and secure IoT infrastructure) [Workshop]”
Laila Partridge, Code On Technologies

13:00 - 13:45 “Using big data to change the face of urban mobility”
Matt George, Bridj

13:45 - 14:30 “Talk title TBD”
David Chudzicki, Sense Home 

14:30 - 15:15 “Brain Power – The World’s First Wearable System for Autism“
Ned Sahin, Brain Power

15:15 - 16:00 “The IoT Data Prism: Capturing Value in the Connected World“
Nyla Beth Gawel, Booz Allen Hamilton

16:00 - 16:30 “Analysis and Visualization Techniques for Environmental IoT Systems”
Rob Purser, Mathworks

16:30 - 17:00 “Deep Learning & The IoT”
Sean Lorenz, LogMeIn


Schedule subject to change.  View the full schedule here: http://www.bostondatafest.com/speaker-workshop-schedule/

results.description:
This event is proudly brought to you by Soccer Beyond!

Learn more on SoccerBeyond.com or Facebook.com/SoccerBeyond.

Details - Fun, interactive, effective.

90min. This is a Coed Soccer Lesson. Please bring a ball if you have. Sneakers, running and turf shoes are fine. Bring some water or sports drink and maybe sun blocker. Please note our Waiver of Liability and 24hr Cancellation Policy below. More details follow.

Rain or Shine - If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Our sessions will be held as scheduled if weather allows. Thunder or snow and ice are among the reasons for sessions to be canceled/ moved. BUT: Don't make assumptions - you will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved. As the weather changes quickly in NYC, occasionally we may make the final decision about 90min prior to session start. If you don't hear from us, the session is on!

Cancelled/ Moved Sessions - You will always get notified!

Every time we have to cancel a session, if possible, we move it to the same day and time of the following week. In this case, all players keep their spots. Please email us prior to the rescheduled event, if you can't make and wish a refund or credit. The 24 hours cancellation policy applies. You will always get notified if a class is canceled/ moved.

Requesting a Refund

To request a refund 1) change your status to "not going" and 2) send us a note with the Paypal transaction number related to the payment for the respective session. Refunds are processed once a week - please be patient.


24 Hours Cancellation Policy

A full refund/ credit will be given if cancellation is received at least 24 hours prior to lesson start. Full payment is required thereafter. Our cancellation policy also applies to package holders.


Waiver of Liability and Hold Harmless Agreement

By RSVP'ing for this event you certify that you are physically fit such as you are able to participate in this program. You therewith voluntarily release CoachFrankNYC/ Soccer Beyond, LLC from any and all liability resulting from or arising out of your participation and/ or receipt of instruction. You read and agree to the WAIVER OF LIABILITY AND HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT to be found on SoccerBeyond.com/pages/waiver.

Please let us know if you have any questions or suggestions.

Coach Frank  
M. [masked]

SoccerBeyond.com
[masked]


Feel free to like us on http://www.facebook.com/SoccerBeyond.

results.description:
Great turnout and games last week. Since the soccer league in Bay 8th St. has started, we are moving to Calvert Vaux park. Here is a map of where we intend to set up at Calvert. If you look at the map, there's two whitish areas. Those have been renovated to artificial soccer fields. If those fields are available we'll play there. If it's full or we get kicked out then we will move to the softball field I marked on the map. Parking is normally plentiful.

As I mentioned last week, please bring your membership dues. New members do not have to pay until their 3rd time. If you want to paypal me, send it to [masked]. Please make sure the funds are from your bank account and not from a credit card!

Questions or problems then give me a call at[masked] but I usually won't be answering as I'll be setting up the field or playing...

***************

 
Attendance will be strictly enforced. No-shows will be marked and posted on the subsequent meetup. First time offenders will be given the benefit of doubt, second time offenders will be warned (consider your name in this email and the number of times you no-showed as warning) and those who miss a third time will be banned, permanently! Those that show up without RSVP to circumvent this will be warned as well. We need to know how many people will show up in order to decide if we have enough people for a game that week.

All new members are allowed to play for free the first three games. If you decide to continue with us then please remit the membership fee. Our season starts on 9/1 and the $10 is good for all games for the year

results.name: Sunday Morning - Second Match

results.description:
THE GAME: Informal Meet Up 7vs7 or (8vs8 depending on location)

Please bring GOOD ATTITUDE. This game is ideally for INTERMEDIATE to ADVANCED players, NOT for BEGINNERS.


There are not scheduled games at this time and location for the Fall, however, we have NO PERMIT. If the field is taken, we might move to Baruch Playground (nearby) or any of the East River Parks/fields.In case we can't play, fee's will be fully refunded.

RSVP GUIDELINES: IMPORTANT:  You must be on the RSVP list to play. If you are not, you will have to wait until someone asks for a substitution. If you RSVP and don't show, you'll be removed from the group for 4 weeks.

PLAY GUIDELINES:

• We usually play for 1.30 or 2 hours max. with a short water break half time in.

• Usually play with small goals


• Please don't come if you can't play at least 90 minutes

• No slide tackles. 

• Respect your teammates and opponents. 

• If you fight, you will be banned from the group, permanently. 

• If you dribble more than you pass - you annoy everybody and will be banned from the group.

•  Refunds are ONLY issued if you change your RSVP more than 24-hrs in advance


• Fees pay for organizer time, meet-up feas and gear

RECOMMENDED GEAR - Turf shoes recommended. No shinguards, we play advanced but friendly.

POSITIONS: Being a pick up game, there are no permanent positions. If you've been playing forward for half the game and someone who's been playing the back line wants to play up front, give up your position and play some defense. When your team lose the ball, don't just stand and watch. Please support your teammates by get back on your side and play some defense. Thanks.

ABOUT THE FIELD - We always play on Turf fields

**INJURIES & DISCLAIMER**: Group Organizer(s) and Group Organization Assumes NO Risk Or individual Liability For Personal Injuries Incurred By Members/Players On The Field Or During Any Of Our Activities: Pick Up Games, Or Other Events. By Agreeing To Play, You Are In Receipt Of This Information, And Thereby Warrant That You Are In Good Health And Assume Personal Responsibility For ALL Physical And Accidental Risks Involved With Playing In Our Group, Including But Not Limited to Falls, Injuries, Contact With Other Players, and Field Conditions.

results.description:
**********

This event is to be rescheduled

 due the illness of Mare the Psychic

 **********

*

PBSN and 8 MEETUPs

Invite You and Your Friends to the

Blue Morel Restaurant and Wine Bar
at
The Westin Governor Morris

Named among the "Top 10 New Restaurants in U.S.

*

Sunday, September 20

Interactive Psychic Gallery Demonstration

and Buffet

with Mare, Internationally Recognized Psychic, Medium and Empath

Morris County

Blue Morel Restaurant and Wine Bar
at
The Westin Governor Morris
click venue name above for directions

2 Whippany Road, Morristown, NJ 07960

*

TIME

*

Gallery ONE
Registration 9:30am
Breakfast Buffet, 9:45am to 11:00pm
Gallery 11:00am to 1:00pm

*

Gallery TWO
Registration 11:45pm 
Brunch Buffet 12 Noon to 1:30pm
Gallery 1:30pm to 4:00pm

*

Mare is an internationally recognized psychic, medium, empath, numerologist, spiritual teacher, healer and "Prayer Warrior." She doesn't use tools in her readings, however, in a group environment she uses your first name and birth date (month and day) to ensure she is picking up on the right energy. Mare then quickly accesses the answer to any type of question asked.

*

THE EVENT

The Interactive Psychic Gallery Demonstration follows the buffet; our psychic, Mare, will take a question from a member of the audience in random order and offer her insight and feedback as a shared experience with all of the participants ... and then continue by taking another question until each participant has asked one question. You may have seen this process on TV shows like John Edwards, Sylvia Browne and the Long Island Medium.

A group reading with Mare is full of surprises. The experience is both entertaining and inspiring. Whether the reading is for you or for others in the Gallery, the audience participants are enthralled. Mare said "It's exciting to witness the connection and see the recognition and understanding in the inquirer's face."

All are welcome to attend. This event is for anyone seeking answers to their questions thru the art and science of parapsychology. Membership is not required. Enjoy the buffet before your scheduled Gallery.

*

All prerpaid participants will be included in a drawing:

Grand Prize is a Bronze Membership with HeartMatch.dating  value $269

2nd Prize, Gallery ONE, is a one Hour reading with IAM Mare, value $150 

2nd Prize, Gallery TWO, is a one Hour reading with IAM Mare,value $150

*

Blue Morel Restaurant and Wine Bar named among the "Top 10 New Restaurants in U.S." combines the finest seasonal ingredients from local, regional, organic and sustainable farms with the culinary creativity of Chef Thomas Ciszak and Chef Kevin Takafuji. Nestled in historic Morristown, Blue Morel creates a farm to table experience serving New American Cuisine, Sushi and a Seafood Raw Bar.

*

Enjoy the Buffet before your Interactive Psychic Gallery Demonstration.

Breakfast Buffet Menu <--- click here to view

Brunch Buffet Menu <--- click here to download pdf

*

Prepaid SIGN UP required.

Friends, Family and Guests are welcome.
This event is for anyone seeking answers to their questions thru the art and science of parapsychology.

Membership is not required

*

COST:

Gallery ONE

purchase $65 tickets thru Eventbrite for 9:30am Breakfast Buffet (included) and Gallery ONE Demonstration<--- click for details 

Gallery TWO

purchase $80 tickets thru Eventbrite for 11:45am Brunch Buffet (included) and Gallery TWO Demonstration<--- click for details

*

Copy and paste the text below into an email with the subject line as "Blue Morel" Fill in the information and then SEND to[masked]

*

ADMISSION PRICE: $11. Pay directly to Nick at the event.

DESCRIPTION:


Whether you want to play competitively, hit around, or even just check out the hot guys and girls, you've come to the right place. I will try to host the badminton events on bi-weekly basis in order to provide you with an badminton experience where you can get your daily exercise in, improve at the game of badminton, and socialize with other fellow badminton-ers, all at the same time!

After the badminton event, we will have lunch together at Flushing.


To have a good play experience, we will put a cap of  10 on the attendee.
Please only RSVP when you are sure you will show up.

WEAR:
Sport cloth and sneaker.

BRING:
Badminton racquets and birdies, bottles of water, towel and clothes to change.
PS.If you don't have a badminton racquet, you can rent one at the center for $4 per day and $20 deposit.

LOCATION:
New York Badminton Center,[masked]th Ave, Flushing, NY 11354 ( enter 34th Ave from College Point Blvd )
New York Badminton Center (NYBC) is designated badminton facility with 6 international tournament standard Badminton floor mats on top of 3″ high wood floor elevation for maximum shock absorbing and pressure reduction to knees and ankles.  Center also equipped with Table Tennis, Weights room, kids room, and spacious resting area, large bathrooms. Center opens 7 days all year around. It offers the convenience for players to play on any of the days they prefer. Center is close to public transportation (about 10 mins walking), street parking is also available.   

For more info about NY Badminton Center, check the link in the reference section below. 


TRANSPORTATION:
Subway: #7 train to Main St. Station, 10-13 min walk.



REFERENCE LINK:

• http://newyorkbadmintoncenter.com/

DISCLAIMER:

http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/pages/Disclaimer

END

results.description:
</a>

Hi everyone,

Randall's Island is a player's heaven. it has gazillions of fields and open space. Make sure to check what field we will use on the map below. 

CARPOOL: Also, if you are driving, please carpool with other players. The meeting spot in Manhattan is 124th street and 2nd avenue 30 minutes before kickoff time.

BIKING: You can also bike there using the footbridge on 103rd street and FDR drive or you can use the RFK Bridge Walkway

A link to better view this map is here: <a href="http://files.meetup.com/526560/Randalls%20Island%20Fields%20Map.pdf">RANDALL'S ISLAND MAP

Please be at the field 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt. We will play for 1.5 hous and you can use cleats since it's a grass field. 


Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 45-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use cleats or turf shoes. Cleats are recommended since it's grass.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and ground kick-ins and big goals-we rotate being goalie.

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:Click here for: Field Location Map.To see an aerial view of the field on Bing Maps: Aerial Map

DirectionsYou can get to Randall's Island by car, bus, walking or biking. Here is the link to the directions: Getting to Randall's Island

The best ways to get there are:


-Taking the A,C,D, 4,5 or 6 train to 125th st stop and walking or biking east over the RFK Bridge.

-Also, taking the M35 bus from the NW corner of 125th Street and Lexington Ave.

-Also biking across the Walk way located on 103rd street and FDR Drive.

If you have any questions about getting there please e-mail or all us at[masked]

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals: If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is grassso please bring cleats, sneakers or all terrain shoes.

Cancellations/Refunds: If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for the next game. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List: If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will be sent an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has just openned :).

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Did you forget to sing? Perhaps after Third Grade, when the peer pressure set in. Perhaps someone picked out the "Gifted and Talented" - and it wasn't you. Or maybe the Nuns made you sing "God Bless America" and someone laughed. Or you were one of the "Blue Birds" - you moved your mouth but didn't make any sound. Or did you sing beautifully in that Elementary School play? Was it the Middle School chorus, where the boys were thrown out and it ended up a Girls Club that made a sound in three parts, so beautiful nothing to this day has extinguished that feeling? Perhaps you were one of the guys who made harmony in the reverb of the Boys Room, or in the audience at the concert, or the sports stadium, or in the shower?

Or maybe you played an instrument that kept your mouth busy, and you never did get the chance to sing? Was it the race of competition for excellence in something, something else, that left you no time?

Was is the implicit warning, between the lines of the praises of privilege, that you should not express yourself? Did you forget that feeling of camaraderie and being a part of something bigger than yourself? Did you forget that amazement you felt at yourself being able to memorize a large piece and give it your all - weeks and months of practice that lead to a performance, or several, that made you feel powerful, hopeful, inspired and you had drawn upon that experience to guide your life? You had that moment, lifted by the magic of the "ordered progression though time and space," that made life so rich, so romantic, so filled with spirit.

And then did you forget?

Forget that feeling, that high, that experience of joy and sadness, playing the part, being a messenger, a vessel. You forgot that there are scientific studies praising the participation in music and art, the health benefits, the raised white blood cell count, the relaxation response, the breathing, the healing power of sound, or just the old saying, "singing is good for you."

Now you have another chance.

Don't miss it.
results.name: Did You Forget to Sing?

results.description:
“…to be successful in life you need values, you need integrity, you need a vision, you need energy, and you need dynamism. And spirituality is the one thing that gives it all to you. If you are healthy, you can see better, you can eat better, you can speak better, you can hear better and you can run better. All this depends on just one thing. Similarly that which enriches your spirit is so essential to enrich all other aspects of life.” -Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, Founder, Art of Living Foundation

Whatever we do in life, it is all directed towards being happy. Why do we even do some service to somebody? It is because it gives some happiness to us. So anything we do in our life is directed towards achieving happiness, greater happiness, and even greater happiness. That’s how the mind goes. Yet, are we happy? Yes, some times. But often not!

This free seminar examines what comes in the way of our happiness. There will be a discussion on tools that can lead us to happiness – tools that every human being is privileged to learn and use. Come, relax, refresh and smile.

results.description:
Thurgood Marshall, whom Gilbert King regards as “the most important American lawyer of the 20th century” argued 32 critical civil rights cases before the US Supreme Court in his position as Executive Director of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund. He won 29 of them including the landmark Brown vs. the Board of Education of Topeka that led to the desegregation of schools throughout America. In 1967 President Johnson nominated Marshall to be the first African- America Associate of the US Supreme Court, a post he would serve for 24 years until he stepped down in 1991. Author Gilbert King will describe how he came to study Marshall by following an early case in which he defended black men in Florida accused of raping a white woman in 1949. Mr. King’s book, Devil in the Grove: Thurgood Marshall, the Groveland Boys and the Dawn of a New America won the coveted Pulitzer Prize in 2013, and was runner-up for the Dayton Literary Peace Prize for non-fiction that same year. Because of his effectiveness and tireless efforts on behalf of minorities in this country, civil rights activist and current congressman from Georgia, John Lewis, regarded Thurgood Marshall as “the Founding Father of the New America.”

Gilbert King has written extensively on the issue of the death penalty in America and the history of the Supreme Court in articles for the New York Times, the Washington Post, and the Marshall Project, and is a frequent contributor to the Smithsonian magazine. In addition to the Pulitzer-prize winning Devil in the Grove, he also published The Execution of Willie Francis in 2008. Originally from Schenectady, he now lives in the neighborhood of All Souls with his wife, two daughters, and a French bulldog named Louis.

Carry the momentum of fall forward! Bring your own ipod & earbuds. We dance walk around the park loop. What is dance walking? It's an improvised form of walking, with music, doing whatever movement comes naturally. It's walking and moving your arms. Or skipping, skitching, low-stepping, sideways running. It's responding to the rhythm, attitude, or story of the music you're hearing. In short, it's having a dance party in your living room, while walking through the park--hilarious and exhilarating. For inspiration, check out:

www.24hoursofhappy.com

results.description:
Soak in the beginning of fall-like weather this Saturday in Prospect Park. 

The park and meditation-- all the simplicity you need to find some inner calm. The first 10 minutes will be a little about meditation/getting comfortable, then 25-30 minutes of guided meditation using the breath, sound and mantra meditation and voila, the remainder for comments, questions and community.

We'll be at the green space east of the picnic house-- on the long meadow! https://www.prospectpark.org/visit-the-park/park-map/.  With your back to the picnic house, walk down the path towards the sun. Then LOOK FOR THE FADED RED BLANKET. 

Remember to wear something comfortable and bring a chair, cushion and/or mat to sit on... bring anything really that will allow you to sit ease-fully for 45 minutes. $5, please.

Jess

results.description:
Uncover the power of a quieter mind and ensure the renewal of a healthier you through movement, breath, and meditation. I welcome each student to come escape the bustle of the city to experience above and find their inner guru in my  class!

WELCOME TO FALL YOGA! 

BEGINNING LABOR DAY WEEKEND...

As the summer draws to an end (sadly for some for us), we look forward to a process of  reaping the harvest and letting go.  Fall is a time of transition and it is evident everywhere around us.  After the glorious celebration of summer, the trees and shrubs are undressing in preparation for the winter, the air is crisping up, and the wind is blowing whispering coming of the winter tides.  Although this may leave us feeling slightly down, empty, and/or anxious, the possibility to strip down to a quiet essence of being and and savor the simplicity is an opportunity for introspection.  Come slow and quiet down with us in a practice to balance the Vata dosha and learn how you can best take care of yourself this season....  

Since March 2013, this donation based Meet Up group has aimed to provide a light-hearted and non-competitive space.  One can expect clear instructions, demonstration, expert hands-on assistance, and achieve greater flexibility, strength, balance, focus, and sense of ease with regular attendance.  

Extra mats and blocks are limited, kindly bring yours if you have them.


*To offset Meetup Organizer's fees, a suggested donation between $7-10 will be greatly appreciated*

Thank you and please do post any questions.  I hope to see you soon! 

Jennifer ( 500 Hour Yoga Alliance Registered  Teacher)

A True Account of a Multiple Murder and Its Consequences
By Truman Capote.

The plains of western Kansas are even lonelier than the sea. Men, farm houses and windmills become specks against the vast sky. At night, the wind seems to have come from hundreds of miles distant. Diesel-engine horns echo immensity. During the day, one drives flat out through shimmering mirages. Highways all roll straight to the point of infinity on a far horizon. Tires click; tumbleweed rustles; Coca-Cola signs  endlessly creak.

On the Indian summer night of Nov. 14, 1959, two criminals visited this haunting geography. With a knife and a 12-gauge shotgun, they robbed and murdered a man and his wife and their son and daughter. The deed filled the scene. It echoed through the lives of all who lived nearby, rushing toward some appalling, mysterious point of psychic infinity. It made haggard men out of the guardians of order. Eventually through a fluke almost as gratuitous as the killing itself, they captured the murderers. On an April night last year, as rain beat on the roof, the two were hanged in a chilly warehouse in the corner of the yard of the Kansas State Penitentiary at Lansing.


Continue to read the review at:

https://www.nytimes.com/books/97/12/28/home/capote-blood2.html

results.description:
LEADER: Louise Parnell ([masked] or[masked] (c)[masked])

RATING: C 3 C

Meet at 10AM in the parking lot behind Confetti restaurant on Ash St. in Piermont. Richard Esnard of the Piermont Historical Society will lead a walk through the birth place of Piermont. We will walk along the Sparkill Creek and he will show us the Rockland Road Bridge which is on the National Register of Historic Places. TCmap 109

*   *   *   *   *   *

Our full hike schedule can be viewed on our website at hudsonhikers.org, and some hikes are also posted on our Facebook page.

After attending two hikes/events, please consider joining the North Jersey Ramapo Chapter of the Adirondack Mountain Club to support our outdoor recreation and conservation activities.  Membership comes with a variety of benefits including a 10% discount at Ramsey Outdoor; our annual holiday party and social; special events such as our traditional day-outing to the Mohonk Mountain House; a subscription to ADK’s bi-monthly magazine, Adirondac; and the opportunity to contribute to the preservation and extension of hiking lands and viewsheds in our region.

New hikers are strongly encouraged to select hikes appropriate to their capabilities. North Jersey Ramapo Chapter hikes are rated for pace (A, B or C), mileage, and terrain (A, B or C), with "C" designating easier hikes and "A" more challenging ones. We recommend that new hikers should first try a "C" or short "B" hike before undertaking a more difficult one; otherwise, you may not fully enjoy the hiking experience. If you have any doubts, please contact the hike leader in advance. 

Pace Ratings: 
     A = Fast - 2.5 mph or faster 
     B = Moderate - about 2 mph 
     C = Easy - 1.5 mph or less 

Distance:Noted in miles 

Terrain Ratings:
     A = Strenuous, long/steep climbs and descents, 
             possible rock scrambling
     B = Moderate climbs and descents
     C = Generally flat with little elevation change 

For example, a hike rated “B 7 A” is a moderately paced hike of approximately 7 miles with steep climbs and/or descents and possible rock scrambling. 

If you join us for a hike, please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness, including ensuring that the hike is appropriate for your level of fitness, that you wear the proper clothing, and bring the proper gear, food and water (see the ADK's recommended Hiking Essentials and guidelines, below).

Leaders have the right, responsibility and sole discretion to refuse any hiker he/she deems to be not properly attired, prepared, or otherwise fit to safely complete the hike. 

HIKERS' GUIDELINES:

  Risks:  As with all physical activities, hiking involves hazards. Persons participate at their own risk and will be asked to sign a statement acknowledging that fact before starting the hike. Prior to the hike please advise the leader of any medical condition or physical impairment that could affect you during the hike.

  Footwear and Clothing:  Wear clothing suited to the weather and carry extra garments for unexpected weather conditions. Dress in thin layers so that you can adjust the number of layers as required to maintain comfort. In winter carry a wool cap and wool or polypropylene gloves or mitts and a windproof shell. Be prepared for rain. Bring a rain jacket and rain pants, preferably of the type that permits venting body moisture. Wear comfortable, sturdy boots/shoes.  Do not wear cotton garments in winter.

  Drink and Food:  Adequate hydration is important year round. Drink frequently during the hike. Carry food to enjoy during the midday lunch stop.

  Other responsibilities:  Hikers with children under 16 and new hikers are required to contact the hike leader in advance to determine if the hike is suitable for them.  Minors under 16 are welcome on day hikes when accompanied by a parent or guardian.  No person under 18 shall participate in overnight outings unless accompanied by a parent or adult sponsor over 21.  The hike leader may refuse to allow a person to hike who is judged to be poorly equipped or unable to do the published hike.  Participants should get to the hike at least 10 minutes prior to the starting time.

  Maps:  The TC number indicates a NY-NJ Trail Conference map for the area of the hike. For example: TC-118 refers to the Southern Harriman Park map.

  Abbreviations:  NCA-No Calls After . . . , Pref.- Leader’s contact preference.

  Expense Sharing:  When car-pooling, passengers are expected to offer the driver funds sufficient to cover the cost of fuel, tolls and parking fees. A $3.00 minimum per person is recommended. Most hike trailhead meeting locations can be found on NY-NJ Trail Conference maps.

  Dog-Friendly Hikes:  Pets are not permitted on hikes unless the hike description clearly states that it is "dog friendly."  If it is, all hikers with dogs must abide by park leash regulations.

NO SHOW/LATE CANCELLATION POLICY:
Please be considerate of event hosts/organizers and others who may want to attend an event by not being a "NO SHOW" (failing to show up when you've RSVP'd "yes") or a "LATE CANCEL" (changing RSVP to a "no" within 24 hours of an event).  If you have a history of No Shows and/or Late Cancels, we may have to bump you to the waiting list for meetups with limited space, in favor of those with a positive attendance history.

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>

results.description:
Wudang Wushu is a style of Chinese Martial arts. It is not very famous in the West, but in China the Taoist Wudang Mountains count as one of the three main centers of martial arts, and to some even the motherland of Tai Chi Chuan. 

The goal of the Wudang Wushu class is to teach basic martial arts coordination and develop a foundation for fighting. It consists of multi-functional physical development and strengthening the musculo-skeletal system. 

Read more about classes here.

Read more about Daria here.

Read more about Kung Fu here.

results.description:
Update: This hike is now full. Send an email to Jae if you'd like to get on the waitlist.

Join us at Breakneck Ridge and Mount Taurus on Sunday September 20. This seven-mile hike is very strenuous and consists of about a half-mile of rock scrambling, steep climbs and declines and approximately 1,260 feet of elevation gain (rated 3D7). If you’re up for the challenge, you’ll be rewarded with spectacular views of the Hudson River. We’ll kick things off by rock scrambling up Breakneck Ridge and then we’ll hike to the top of Mount Taurus. We’ll end our journey in downtown Cold Spring where we’ll grab some ice cream before heading back home. Also to note, this will be Silja Tobin’s first co-lead!

If you’re interested in joining this hike, please register by sending an email to [masked]. We’re limiting this hike to the first 12-people to register. Anyone with questions about their ability to do the hike should speak with the co-leaders before registering.

For more information, please visit the AMC event page: http://bit.ly/1Nr0HLU

Like us on Facebook for event updates and invites.
results.name: Young Members – Breakneck Ridge and Mount Taurus Hike

results.description:
This is a chance for you to see all of both parks in a day. We will ride nearly all trails making a 25 mile loop. This is one of the most sceenic bicycle rides I know of in this area. It is 25 miles round trip through 2 parks, Mohonk Preserve and Minawaska State Park. Although you do not have to be a mountain biker, this ride is not for beginners. This is in advanced ride mainly because of the high intensity aerobic capacity needed for the 2.5 hrs of climbing. You will need to have a strong arobic base and a good fitness endurance level to do this ride. It will take us 2.5 hrs to get to the top, (Awosting beach) don't forget to bring your gargoyles and swimsuit cuz we will be there for an hour swimming @ Awosting beach where there is a lifeguard. This ride starts from the bottom parking lot at the base of Mohonk Mountain at the Pine Street parking lot entrance to the park. From the time your wheels hit the ground, the first 2.5 hrs will be all climbing with consistent rewarding views as you will be riding along the exposed rockface of the mountain for more than half the climb . We will pass rock climbers climbing as we cut through the Gunks we will then be rewarded with generous views of valleys and neighboring Mountains as we ankle through our pedal stroke almost anaerobicly! If you have not been here, you need to go at least once, it is something everyone needs to see at least once in your life the first time I was there it looked exactly like the places I have been to in parts of Europe . At times, it's like riding in Colorado.... Do not worry, it is not all uphill, once we get to the beach it's 95% downhill back to the car takes about an hour & 10 minutes to get back down to the lower lot. Don't forget to take the things with you needed to fix a flat

Trails are hard packed, gravel carriage double track roads. A, mountain bike, Hybred, or Cyclecross which is a road bike with beefy tires & special breaks for the mud; these are the types of bicycles that will be needed for this ride. I prefer a Mountain Bike or a hybrid although I have ridden my road bike here with oversized hybrid type mountain tires. This is like a road ride in the woods for those who ride road bikes. The terrain its like riding a hilly rail trail, we will stop for breaks at the Gunks, the waterfall, Lake Minawaska, Castle Point and finally Awosting Beach; (the top) This is a 3.5 hr round trip ride actual riding time, be sure to be in shape for this, bring plenty of food, snacks and water. The return route back will be a long decent, there is over an hour of rolling hills; 95% downhill, rolling back to the car. And remember don't forget to bring the things with you needed to change a flat

After the ride we will stop at either the gilded otter or buccas for some long awaited well deserved food.

We will meet in the lot at the end of pine road you will see my tandem bike on the roof rack

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. results.description:
CATSKILL 3500 BUSHWHACK!
Vly and Bearpen Mountains

HUNTING SEASON HAS BEGUN, PLEASE WEAR BRIGHT COLORS!!!!!


6.5 miles, 2000 feet rise, 4-5 hours - Map 145 or 142
Careful where you park - BE EARLY
Leave no Trace


Please have a map and compass for this hike.  For bushwacks, I also recommend long pants and eye protection. 

Please check and make sure the pin marked on this site is correct on your GPS, sometimes they do not work correctly.  There is no cell service usually at the starting sites, so I will not know if you are lost or late.

Intermediate pace, we will hit Vly's canister first, then head over to Bearpen.

View on Bearpen

---

The DEC limits group size in this area to 20.

---

WARNING REGARDING BUSHWHACKS: "Bushwhacks" are hikes that go off of maintained trails and through pure wilderness.  Please make sure you are very confident in your ability to navigate through the woods without trails since it is very easy to get lost in these forests, especially in the summer.  Map & Compass REQUIRED. GPS is also recommended, but it is not a substitute for a map & compass and the skills to use them effectively.

---

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

results.description:
2nd Annual Pre Meet Magento NY Hackathon

Hosted by Luis Colon

Sponorsored by


What is a Hackathon?

A hackathon is an event organized by the community. It is a conference workshop versus casual meetup event. During the day, developers programming in small teams and follow up with presentations (see format below). In the evening it's time to go to drink a beer with the other participants and, particularly, make lots of friends and have fun!

The purpose of a hackathon is to just take a step back and resolve the problems that we suffer from on regular days, but we usually fix it with a few dirty fixes or until a less busy day (All which is: never).

Magento Hackathons

The first Magento hackathon took place in March 2012 in Germany, and in early 2014 we even have had an online hackathon spanning 8 countries. This will be the second Magento Hackathon in NYC!

Who should attend the hackathon?

Anyone with extensive PHP knowledge and some Magento experience is welcome. It is important to have these requirements so that you can have a meaningful experience at the hackathon and can really contribute something. What do you need to bring?
      -Your laptop with a clean version of Magento 1.8 installed.
      -A github account
      -Ideas for projects to present for hacking

Tickets to Meet Magento NY must be purchased separately and are not required to attend the hackathon.

SCHEDULE


Sept 20 - Day 1 - Pre Meet Magento NY

Location TBD

10:30am to 12:00pm - Gathering projects and form teams. Start programming. Code, code and more code


12:00pm to 1:00pm - Lunch - Sandwiches and Salad

5:00pm to 6:00pm - Pizza and / or something with code -)


6:00pm - Project status

9:00 - Close / Beer time!

Sept 22 - Day 2 - Meet Magento NY at Digital Sandbox Conference Center

55 Broad Street, New York, NY

1:00am - 12:00am Final Project Presentations and Voting

*schedule subject to change


View more information about the Meet Magento NY Conference at http://ny.meet-magento.com
results.name: Pre Meet Magento NY Hackathon

results.description:
Governor's Island is a beautiful little island that has been converted into a park. To get there, you need to take a ferry. It's $2 for a roundtrip, but on Saturday mornings it is free.

I usually go every summer and I haven't been there yet this year...I thought it'd be fun to get together for an end-of-the-summer field day.

Bring games and sports equipment if you like....there is a lot of open space here.

For a list of food trucks/stands: http://govisland.com/activities/food

Alcohol is not permitted.

You can bring non-motorized bikes on the ferry and ride them on the island. There are also bikes there to rent (including the 4 person surrey bicycles which I really wanna try!)

Bring CASH just in case.

The ferry that goes to Governor's Island departs from the Battery Maritime Building....however, I think I would be easier to meet IN FRONT of the State Island Ferry building, and then walk over (less than a block) together.

You can take the 4, 5 to Bowling Green, the 1 to South Ferry, or the R to Whitehall St. South Ferry. As always, check the train schedule beforehand. If you are late, you can still get to the island on your own on a later ferry....but it will not be my responsibility to come find you.

Update (Posted on Thursday, Aug. 27 at 2:42 PM): I am postponing this event.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet IN FRONT of the Staten Island Ferry building, and then take the ferry from the Battery Maritime Building to Governor's Island together. As always, message me your phone number just in case.
results.name: Governor's Island

Please join us for today's service led by Rev. Paul Dodenhoff. Polls continue to show that many people consider themselves "spiritual but not religious." Today we'll take a look at the 19th century Transcendentalist movement, which included such luminaries as Ralph Waldo Emerson, Henry David Thoreau, and Margaret Fuller, and explore some of the ways in which it gave birth to the Spiritual But Not Religious phenomenon.

Bring a friend and stay for coffee and good conversation. We look forward to seeing you!

results.description:
Please read carefully: This event is being sponsored by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people registered on this Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending please contact the event host at [masked].

Our tours are specifically designed for people who live, work and play in the New York Area.  It is our goal to open your eyes to historical sites and info that you may walk past every day!  Our tours are fun ways to learn about the city while socializing with other fun people from our group. It is amazing that Manhattan, which was once known as the Island of Rolling Hills, has transformed into the Concrete Canyon it is today.  Along the way your professional guide will share historical facts and show you a photographic history that will amaze you.  Be a tourist in your own city and sign up today! Following the tour you can join our party at The Columbus Avenue Street Festival.

Your guide will share with you the history of the park from its heyday to decline and then rebirth. He will show you amazing pictures  from before the park was there to vintage shots from the late 18 and 1900's.  You will learn of it's construction, design, special secrets and more as the sun shines on a  spring day.

The tour lasts about 90 minutes and following the walk you can join us at the NYSN beer garden at The Columbus Avenue Street Festival at 85th and Columbus (where the tour ends).

Can I come alone? Yes 98% of those attending usually come on their own.

What to wear: Summer casual

What to expect: We usually have 15-30 people mostly ages 20's - 40's (and some 50's). Everyone is usually from the area and ready to socialize while learning.

How do I pay?  Please bring exact change $15

How do I get there?  The B,C stops closest at 72nd and CPW.  The 1 stops at B'way and 68th.  Check www.mta.info for weekend service changes.

How wll I find the group?  The tour guide will have a sign that says NYSN/Meet Up

In case or rain and the tour is canceled you may switch to a future date or get a refund.

If there does not seem to be a lot of people registered on this Meet Up, are there more people going?

  Yes as explained, this event is being promoted by several Meet Up groups and

www.newyorksocialnetwork.com

.  There will be tons of people attending.  If you want to know exact numbers or have any questions you can contact the event organizer directly at [masked] or call[masked]

results.description:
http://www.nysec.org/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/Massimo-by%20Simon%20Wardenier.jpg?itok=TMGlHoez Massimo Pigliucci

Meg Chapman, Presides 

Stoicism is an ancient Greco-Roman philosophy of ethics and resilience. It was practiced by emperors like Marcus Aurelius, as well as former slaves like the teacher Epictetus. It taught that the most important thing in life is to develop one’s moral character, and that we should live according to our nature, i.e., as social beings capable of reason. Stoicism is experiencing a surprising comeback these days, positioning itself as the Western answer to Buddhism, with which it shares a number of similarities. In this talk I will explain the basics of Stoicism and argue that it is a philosophy highly suitable to the complexities of life in the 21st century. 

Massimo Pigliucci is a biologist and philosopher at the City University of New York. His main interests are in the philosophy of science and pseudoscience. He is the editor-in-chief of the online magazine Scientia Salon, and his latest book (co-edited with Maarten Boudry) is Philosophy of Pseudoscience: Reconsidering the Demarcation Problem (Chicago Press)

Entry to our 100-year-old building and meeting rooms is available for most wheelchair users with prior arrangements. Please call ahead  [masked] x 107) for setup of our portable system and plan to arrive one hour before start time.

<a>
</a>

results.description:
$10.  $5 for Students and Seniors.  Does not include admission to Merchant's House Museum.  This tour has no organizer and repeats the third Sunday of every month until December.  


Join us for a journey back in time to the elite ‘Bond Street area’, home to Astors, Vanderbilts, Delanos — and the Tredwells, who lived in the Merchant’s House. You’ll walk the footsteps of these wealthy mercantile families whose elegant Federal mansions once lined the tranquil cobblestone streets. Our tour passes by iconic landmarks such as the imposing Colonnade Row, the Public Theater, and The Cooper Union, where Lincoln gave his ‘right makes might’ speech. On the bustling Astor Place, imagine the drama of events that led to the Opera House riot of 1849, among the bloodiest in American history. And visit the site of the scandalous 1857 Bond Street murder of Harvey Burdell, one of the City’s still unsolved crimes.

Tours are one hour and begin promptly. Limited to 20 people (on a first-come, first-served basis). Tours are canceled in the case of heavy rain, snow, or extreme heat and cold advisories.

Contact numbers provided at:  http://www.nycgovparks.org/events/2015/09/20/a-walking-tour-of-historic-19th-century-noho
results.name: FYI:  A Walking Tour of Historic 19th Century Noho

results.description:
Calling all yogis new and seasoned! I'm new to the area and I'm a certified Yoga Instructor. I'd love to meet new people and enjoy the extraordinary parks we have in the Bayside area by bringing together like-minded folks to create community and connect with each other through the powerful practice of yoga!!! Yoga is great for relieving stress, dealing with anxiety, getting in shape and attuning to self awareness. The word yoga means "union" and often refers to uniting the breath and the body through breathing exercises and "asana" which are the postures used in the physical practice of yoga. And while connecting to our inner self is super important it's also essential to connect the world and people around us! I hope you'll join me as we celebrate the last weeks of summer with outdoor yoga classes! Each class will last about an hour. Please bring your own yoga mat, water (snacks if you want to stay after and eat) and whatever else you need to feel comfortable sitting and moving. There is a $10.00 suggested donation for participating. Thank you. Blessings & Light.

results.description:
Come, Come, Whoever You Are

Speaker: Jone Johnson Lewis  


Program Description: This title for this program comes from a poem written originally in the 13th century, about 800 years ago:


Come, come, whoever you are.
Wanderer, worshipper, lover of leaving — it doesn’t matter,
Ours is not a caravan of despair.
Come, though you have broken your vows a thousand times,
Come, come again, come.

Come join us — some for the first time, some for the thousandth time, most somewhere between. Whether this is your first or your thousandth time – welcome. Welcome to a place where there is a weekly gathering of people with a variety of beliefs and backgrounds, a time and place to seek the highest – to take time from busy or isolated lives to meet with others who also want to grow and develop our capacity to live according to our values.

About the Speaker: Jone Johnson Lewis is the new clergy Leader at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. Jone has been an Ethical Culture Leader since 1991, serving Ethical Societies in Chicago, Northern Virginia and Brooklyn. She's currently the President of the National Council of Leaders and a member of the American Ethical Union's Membership Committee.

Sunday programs are held at 11:00 AM at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. For more information, please visit our website: <a>http://www.rysec.org </a>;
results.how_to_find_us: Directions on website or call the office during the week.

results.description: The Sunday School at the Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County helps children aged 2-14 explore and develop their moral and critical thinking skills through fun and interactive lessons and field trips. We meet weekly at 11am on Sundays for 1.5 hours while the adults of the Ethical Culture Society are attending the platform meeting. Our wide ranging curriculum allows kids to examine themselves, their community and the world in general. We teach about different cultures, philosophies and religions. We encourage our students to ask questions, think for themselves and make up their own minds about the bigger questions in life. Our children develop strong values and ethical standpoints. The Sunday School Graduation Rite of Passage, completed by our 8th graders, allows them to present to the community how their Sunday School experience has informed their moral and ethical development.
