results.description:
My favorite adult ed speaker!!!


 Professor Gary Dorrien, whom Cornell West has called “the preeminent social ethicist in North America today,” is the author of The New Abolition: W.E.B. Du Bois and the Black Social Gospel - newly released this month by Yale University Press. Drawing upon the resources of this treatise he will address issues presented by American theologians Reverdy Ransom and Reinhold Niebuhr on the quest for racial and social justice in America.

Sept 20: Defying White Supremacy: Reverdy Ransom and the Black Social Gospel
Sept 27: The Niebuhr Problem: Reinhold Niebuhr and the Social Gospel in Black & White

Gary Dorrien, Ph.D is the Reinhold Niebuhr Professor of Theology and Social Ethics at Union Theological Seminary in New York City, Professor of Religion at Columbia University, and a Visiting Lecturer at the Harvard Divinity School. The author of 17 books and some 275 articles ranging across the fields of ethics, social theory, theology, philosophy, politics, economics and history, he has a long history of active participation in social justice organizations. His book Economy, Difference, Empire: Social Ethics for Social Justice (2010) is based on his lectures on economic democracy, racial and gender justice, and anti-imperial politics. More recently Professor Dorrien published a critique of the Obama presidency, The Obama Question: A Progressive Perspective (2012), and lectured widely on it. More than 40 reviewers have described his trilogy, The Making of American Liberal Theology [masked]) as the definitive work on the history of liberal theological thought from the colonial era to the present.

results.description:
Are you looking to BALANCE your training & stretching?

Are you looking for RELIEF from joint wear, tightness, pain, and/or discomfort?

Looking for a complementary training to ENHANCE your overall well being on and off the track?

Would you like to RELEASE physical, mental and emotional tensions?

About Yin Yang Yoga...A typical Yoga class is ‘Yang’ in style and focuses on active heating and muscular contraction - by combining it with ‘Yin’, a more passive, nourishing, and cooling practice, this uniquely designed class WILL balance your whole being in training!

Why For Runners/Athletes? - Lengthening and releasing effect from repetitive movements (overuse) on sheets of connective tissue (fascia) can overtime shorten and tighten in ingrained patterns around muscles. This can make one more prone to having injuries, abnormal posture, and inefficiency, as well as asymmetrical weakening. By targeting selected and rotated key areas in weekly Yin Yang Yoga class, one can better release tension, move with ease, and benefit from improved posture and injury prevention.

The Yin Yang Yoga for Runners class begins with series of held Yin floor postures to open the meridian channels/chakras, or the subtle pathways of the body. While surrendering into the edge of each pose for 2-5 minutes, students are guided in the cultivation of observance and breath, as they experience release of connective tissues and the stagnant energy around the hips, thighs, and lower back. Awareness is guided to sensations in the body that can be grounding and powerful experience of the NOW. The Yang or moving practice allows students to integrate the newly released energy, joint spaces for circulation, and flexibility, into active strengthening postures and movement sequences. Freedom of breath, alignment, and mental clarity will be elicited deeply during, after the class, and into one's training.

After our INTRO CLASS ON 9/10: "Jennifer is an awesome instructor. Her sessions are informative and her teaching style is patient, clear and inspires me to attain increased fitness. I look forward to attending her class. The very next day I was able to push through my usual 3-4 miles to complete a 6 mile run." Sandra

AND another student reported achieving best time running a 18 mile course...


**10 Classes Only - Join weekly for maximum benefits and donate suggested $15 per class for this this performance enhancing class not offered anywhere else in NYC!


PLEASE RSVP "YES" only if you will make it to class (or update), as space is limited to 15 -20, and bring a mat if you have one.

See you and/or would you please pass this limited opportunity on? Thank you!

Namaste, Jennifer, RYT-500hr

results.description:
Welcome back to the Uncommons where each weekend we meet at NYC's very own gaming cafe for a Sunday afternoon full of board games, card games, and ponies!

There is a $10(+tax) rental fee which covers your stay for the entire afternoon until closing at 11 PM(that's nearly 12 hours of gaming if you show up early). More often than not we stay and play games all the way until closing.

The Uncommons hosts a wide variety of games, and our group usually makes a point to try out new games frequently, as well as playing some of our old favorites - from Ticket to Ride to King of Tokyo there's guaranteed to be something there for you.

The Uncommons tends to get a little crowded on weekends, and we cannot guarantee a seat for anyone in particular who shows up late, though if you come around 11:30 AM - Noon there likely won't be too much hassle finding space. Do try to limit the amount of stuff you bring with you though, as space is at a premium. Feel free to bring a plushie along though, as there's always room for Ponies.

How to get there: The nearest subway stop is West 4th St, off of the A, C, E, B, D, F and M and Christopher St/Sheridan Square on the 1 line isn't much farther. If you don't mind a walk, you can also hike down from 14th St/Union Sq (4, 5, 6) or Astor Pl (6).

results.description:
To get a spot: answer the RSVP questions! Otherwise you will probably be removed from the list.  

We'll hike a beautiful section of the AT and spend considerable time at a lovely lake.  Yes, options!

I consider this a moderate hike.  On the HVH scale, it's easy.  So please, no hard-corps,must-keep-moving hikers.  At the same time, no couch slouchers either.  We'll climb almost a 1,000 vertical feet and generally keep a moderate pace, though we'll have a good number of stops.  And a long one at the lake.

A few weeks ago some (expletive deleted) people left trash at the lake.  I'll have heavy-duty trash bags and those willing to help will be rewarded with my thanks.  The hike back to the road from the lake is relatively short.

Swimming is illegal but often happens.  

If you can offer a ride, please mention it in the comments...and from where.  If you need a ride, likewise.  It's nice if riders offer to chip in something for gas/tolls.

---------------------------------------------------------------

The FINE PRINT: YOU MUST READ!!!

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. 


If you join us for a hike (or any other event), you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, familiarize yourself with the area, and bring the proper gear.  Ask questions if there is anything you don't understand.  

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.

Mabon: Your harvest-time invitation to reconnect and align with what matters. The holiday of the autumnal equinox, Harvest Home, Mabon, the Feast of the Ingathering, Meán Fómhair or Alban Elfed (in Neo-Druid traditions), is a Pagan ritual of thanksgiving for the fruits of the earth and a recognition of the need to share them to secure the blessings of the Goddess and the God during the coming winter months... 


If you've been following me or my garden page on facebook, you've seen that the 'gods/goddesses' have been very good to use this harvest season! i'll definitely have some great treats in store for this gathering, see if you can outdo me by MAKING something even more amazing with your own two hands to share with all

The Cornucopia, or Horn of Plenty, is a traditional symbol for Mabon. It is a wonderful symbol for the wealth of harvest and is beautifully balanced symbol which is both male (phallic) and female (hollow and receptive)

this may well be the last party here of the year so it would be wonderful to see as many friends as possible and really have an outrageous spread ! I invite you to really do it up ,be creative and make this celebration special, because it is!!! :)
Please RSVP! So i know who's coming! .
Disclaimer: this will NOT be a religious or spiritual celebration in the theological sense, i myself am atheist. just wanted to clear up any confusions there! but Molly will be in attendance with me, and mayyy be willing to go into some detail on Celtic Mythology and pagan-shamanism as those are subjects she has expertise in! it truly is fascinating and resonates very much with me.


Here's the boiler plate details:
------------------------------------
WHAT TO BRING :
A vegan meal , Snacks or beverage to feed 5+ persons .
Beer/Wine etc welcome!
**A $10 donation will be asked of those coming empty handed.**

!!! PLEASE Bring your "Bliss-Ware" (A real plate, cup and utensils,NOT disposable) !!! We need to have a quick easy cleanup, and hope to produce Zero Garbage! that means no disposable plates/forks/cups will be here.Please don't bring them either ** If you forget,I'll have sets to rent for $5.**newbies get a pass, oldies get the riot act!


Bring drums,guitars and other instruments! bring friends & family, (have them RSVP if possible or comment with your tally)

Pets welcome!. s'long as they play nice!
kids welcome!, s'long as they don't bite.

NEW! :

1. Give-Away pile : anything you would like to pass on (that you believe someone may really want!) items not taken at the end may be disposed of so please check before you leave and retrieve!.

2. Community board: leave a card,flyer , post your haves & wants ,suggestions etc.

3.Artist Tables: do you make something(s) you'd like to display or vend? contact us !

Have an idea you think would benefit this community ? get in touch!

we can designate a space/time for talks,workshops, demos or performances. Write us with your event ideas : [masked]

results.description:
This is a weekly introductory improv class taught Sundays from 12pm-3pm.

-- Are you a bit shy and looking to get more comfortable with your public speaking? 

-- Are you a working professional hoping to be a bit more spontaneous during your meetings and interactions with co-workers? 

-- Or are you an actor or improv comedian looking to take your craft to the next level or get more reps?

Then this is the class for you! In this class, you will learn the fundamentals of scene work (role playing). You'll be on your feet quite a bit as I'm believer that you learn (and have more fun) through doing rather than hearing an instructor talk. Brief individual notes will be given, if that's what you're looking for, and tailored to your level of experience. At the end of each class, I'm confident you'll feel a sense of accomplishment that will leave you more energized and excited to tackle the challenges of everyday life, whether at your work place or in your personal life. 

This class is $10.  If money is an issue for you, let me know and we can work something out.  The cost goes to pay for the cost of the room rental, Meetup fees, and website.  

Hope to see you there!


Steve

www.improvnow.com

www.facebook.com/improvnow

Steve Ling is an alumnus of the improv programs of the Upright Citizens Brigade, Peoples Improv Theater, Magnet Theater, & Annoyance Theater. He regularly produces and performs improv, musical improv, & hip hop improv across NYC.

A small, supportive group for artists of all types to come together and talk about and share their creative projects in a fun, non-judgmental environment. New members welcome. (Each person pays $1 cash at the meetings, just to help offset the costs of having the group hosted here on MeetUp.com.)

Every week, we meet from 12:00 pm to 2:00 pm. Usually, we work through Julia Cameron's creativity building techniques (for example those in The Artist's Way Finding Water, and The Prosperous Heart). We start each session discussing the current week's activity (morning pages, artist's dates, synchronicities, creative endeavors, etc) and then usually we participate in an agreed upon exercise/task (bring paper and pen please).


This is the third Sunday of the month, so we will be sharing our artistic projects in a kind of "Show & Tell" so that we can get to know each other's work and support it. Not mandatory - only for those who wish to share or present their work.


This is a very creative and supportive small group. Please join us.

venue.name: Outside of the northbound side of the Metro-North Greystone Station

results.description:
PLEASE READ THE INFORMATION BELOW CAREFULLY, ESPECIALLY THE BOLD TYPE AND TRANSPORTATION SECTION.

If you have any questions for me, please contact me through my private Meetup inbox. The organizer for this Meetup event is John, who is listed on the top of the "going list" with a photo. Thank you.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you very much.

Description:  We'll start the walk from the Metro-North Greystone Station. We will be visiting Untermyer Gardens, which is an historic park in Yonkers, New York (There is no entry fee to visit Untermyer Gardens.) Located on a hillside above the Hudson River, the park has the Walled Garden that is divided into quadrants by waterways and bordered by crenellated walls anchored by octagonal towers; the Temple of Love, which is the centerpiece for rock gardens; and the spectacular Vista Overlook that was modeled on a similar series of long descending stairs at the Villa D'Este in Italy.

Below is the Temple of the Sky in the Walled Garden at the Untermyer Gardens.

Below is the Vista Overlook (with ancient Roman columns imported from Italy) at the Untermyer Gardens. The Overlook has breathtaking views of the Hudson River and Palisades Cliffs.

Below is the long descending stairs that lead down to the Vista Overlook.

Below is the view from the amphitheater at the Untermyer Gardens.

Below is the Lion(at the old Gatehouse) located at the bottom of the hillside in the Untermyer Gardens. This section of the Untermyer Gardens is in ruins (In England, they used to traditionally have fake ruins for their gardens. This Gatehouse area is real ruins that will remain in ruins.) There is also a sculpture of a headless horse at the Gatehouse.

There is no admission fee to the Untermyer Gardens. However, dogs are not allowed in the park and gardens with the exception of service animals, which are always welcome.

Below is a ventilator on the Old Croton Aqueduct path. The Old Croton Aqueduct is an easy, leveled dirt path. We'll be walking on the Old Croton Aqueduct, which will connect us to the Untermyer Gardens. In 1992, the Old Croton Aqueduct was awarded National Historic Landmark status.

BRING LUNCH, SUN PROTECTION, WATER, COMFORTABLE WALKING SHOES, AND AN EXTRA LAYER OF CLOTHING. THERE IS NO PLACE TO BUY LUNCH ALONG THE WAY.

This is a sociable walk along a very scenic route filled with interesting places. Although I will comment on some things (the architecture, sculpture, and history of Greystone and Untermeyer Gardens) along the way, this is not one of my walking tours.

This walk is about 4 1/2 miles and moderate paced. If you think that you will be lagging behind with a moderate pace, then this type of walk is not good for you. At the beginning of the walk, there will be gradual uphill walking, mostly in the shade. Later on, we will be walking on level ground or going mostly downhill.

We will be walking on pavement and easy dirt pathways, including the Old Croton Aqueduct and carriage trails. Have comfortable walking shoes.

Below is the Walled Garden at the Untermyer Gardens.

Cost: The cost of this event is $2 per person, which is paid at the start of the walk. This is for the organizer's Meetup preparation costs and fees.

If you are registered for this walk and can't attend, please change your RSVP online from "YES" to "NO". There is no need to post why you can't make the event. Thank you very much.

Meeting Time: The meeting time is (before lunch) at 12:00 PM. (BRING YOUR LUNCH. THERE IS NO PLACE TO BUY LUNCH ALONG THE WAY.)

Meeting Place: The meeting place is outside of the northbound side of the Metro-North Greystone Station. IF THE METRO-NORTH TRAIN IS LATE, THE ORGANIZER WILL WAIT FOR THE LATE-ARRIVING TRAIN.

Before the walk, there are no restrooms available at the Metro-North Greystone Station (there are no stores or shops near this station). RESTROOMS ARE AVAILABLE ON THE METRO-NORTH TRAIN. LATER ON, RESTROOMS WILL BE AVAILABLE ON THE GROUNDS OF UNTERMYER GARDENS.

BELOW ARE THE TRANSPORTATION OPTIONS.

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION BY METRO-NORTH: Take the No. 1 subway train to Marble Hill/225th Street (UNFORTUNATELY, BECAUSE OF SUBWAY CONSTRUCTION SCHEDULED ON THE NO. 1 SUBWAY LINE THIS WEEKEND, YOU WILL HAVE TO TAKE A FREE SHUTTLE BUS INSTEAD OF THE TRAIN, SO ALLOW EXTRA TIME.), which is one block from the Metro-North's Marble Hill station. Then take the 11:42 AM Metro-North train from Marble Hill to Greystone, arriving at 11:59 AM. Before boarding the train, buy a ticket at the Marble Hill station's vending machine. Get a ticket from Marble Hill to Greystone (Regular fare is $3.00 one way; senior fare [65 years and older] is $1.50 one way). You can buy two tickets (one for Marble Hill to Greystone and one for Greystone back to Marble Hill). PURCHASING A REGULAR FARE TICKET ON BOARD THE TRAIN IS CONSIDERABLY MORE EXPENSIVE. However, seniors citizens who show the proper identification may purchase a ticket on board the train without paying the penalty of the higher on board prices. (This Marble Hill Metro-North station is a good option for those who live on the West Side of Manhattan or have easy access to the No. 1 subway line.)

MORE PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION OPTIONS BY METRO-NORTH:

Then take the 11:20 AM Metro-North train from Grand Central Terminal to Greystone, arriving at 11:59 AM. Before boarding the train, buy a ticket. Get a ticket from Grand Central Terminal to Greystone (Regular fare is $7.75 one way; senior fare [65 years and older] is $5.25 one way). You can buy two tickets (one for Grand Central Terminal to Greystone and one for Greystone back to Grand Central Terminal). PURCHASING A REGULAR FARE TICKET ON BOARD THE TRAIN IS CONSIDERABLY MORE EXPENSIVE. However, seniors citizens who show the proper identification may purchase a ticket on board the train without paying the penalty of the higher on board prices.

BELOW IS A SCHEDULE OF THE METRO-NORTH'S HUDSON LINE ON THE WEEKEND:

http://web.mta.info/mnr/html/planning/schedules/pdf/HUD_SS_apr262015.pdf

DRIVING: You can park your car for the entire walk at the Greystone Metro-North parking lot, which is free on the weekends. However, read carefully all the parking signs. For example, if you have a large vehicle don't park in a parking spot reserved for a compact vehicle. Wait for the train people outside of the northbound side of the station.

Finishing Time/Place: We will be finishing back at the Metro-North Greystone Station at about 4:20 PM. The return train arrives at Greystone at 4:58 PM, stopping in Marble Hill at 5:15 PM and Grand Central Terminal at 5:42 PM. (We might even have time to catch the earlier train, which is the 4:27 PM.)

Rainy conditions cancels this walk. Therefore, if it is raining, or the forecast is for rainy conditions, I will post a cancellation notice Sunday morning. If I don't post a cancellation notice, I plan to be at the meeting place. (If I do cancel the walk, I will also post a cancellation notice in the Discussion Board.) 

Below is the Temple of Love at the Untermyer Gardens. The Hudson River and Palisades Cliffs are in the background. We will have lunch or a picnic around the Temple of Love. There are many rocks to sit on but you could also bring a blanket if you want.
results.name: Untermyer Gardens Walk (Sept. 20)

results.description:
Dear Members:

NYC Ferments member Chef Natsuko Yamawaki will be hosting a class on how to make amazake, a traditional Japanese drink rich in enzymes.  The class is limited to 6 people so RSVP and send in your deposit ASAP if you are interested (see below).


Thanks!

Angela Davis

NYC Ferments Co-Organizer

How to make your own Amazake at home

Although Amazake literally means “sweet sake,” it does not contain any alcohol. A deliciously sweet and creamy natural beverage, nowadays Amazake is enjoyed as a warming winter drink . However, during the Edo period of Japanese history (think samurai and geisha), Amazake was enjoyed year round. Children and the elderly drank Amazake to combat the exhausting effects of extreme heat during the summer monsoon season.

Amazake can be thought of as a natural predecessor to today’s energy drinks. It contains so many natural vitamins and nutrients that itis often called a “natural IV drip.” Amazake is made with koji which is cultured rice that has been incubated overnight to produce a lightly fermented food rich in enzymes and nutrients. Amazake is easy to make at home. Learn to make your own Amazake to use in cooking and baking – and as a healthy base for your daily smoothie! In this workshop, you will learn how to make your own Amazake at home and how to use it for your diet.

Admission Fee: $5０

This class will cover:

• What is Amazake?


• How to make great taste  Amazake.

• Demonstration of how to make Amazake at home

• Tasting Amazake and Lunch made with Amazake. 　

• Grilled vegetable with Miso Amazake Dip 　

• Kale and Quinoa with Amazake Salad Dressing 　

• Creamy carrot Ginger Amazake soup 　 　

• Amazake Ice  cream  etc...

To register you must contact Chef Natsuko Yamawaki at [masked]. 


Natsuko will send you instructions on how to mail your $25 deposit.
results.name: Let's Make Amazake with Chef Natsuko Yamawaki! 9.20

Please read carefully: This event is being sponsored by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people registered on this Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending please contact the event host at [masked].

Experience Central Park in a whole new way with our Central Park Scavenger Hunt!  It is a fun way to meet new people or hang out with familiar friends in NYC's Urban Oasis! If you don't have a team we will set you up on one as you set out to find fun and historical things that are already part of the park.  Following the hunt you can join members of NYSN who are participating in other activities that day at The NYSN Beer Garden at The Columbus Avenue Street Festival.How it works:

-Come alone or with friends to The Firehouse Tavern at 12pm.  We will set up the teams (teams of 5 only)

-Each team will have 90 minutes to find as many clues at they can inside the park (clues will be in historical markers, wildlife, street performers, tourists, fountains, statues, bridges and hidden secrets)

-At the end of the 90 minutes each team will return to The Firehouse Tavern to see which group has uncovered the most clues to win prizes!

Can I come alone?  Yes, 95% of those attending will be coming on their own.  If you come alone we will put you on a team with other fun members.

Dress code: Summer Casual

Is this going to be hard or do I need experience?  No this is a fun hunt and designed to make the clues easy to find.

What if it rains? We will send updates before the event.

How do I pay?  Please bring exact change $10 If there does not seem to be a lot of people registered on this Meet Up, are there more people going?  Yes as explained, this event is being promoted by several Meet Up groups and www.newyorksocialnetwork.com.  There will be tons of people attending.  If you want to know exact numbers or have any questions you can contact the event organizer directly at [masked] or call[masked]

Please read carefully: This event is being sponsored by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people registered on this Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending please contact the event host at [masked].

The Columbus Avenue Street Festival is the largest and most diverse street festival in NYC!  Unlike other street fairs, the Columbus Avenue festival features the most food options from the dozens of restaurants along Columbus Avenue. Join members of NYSN and their friends for a fun afternoon of socializing, eating, drinking, live music and football!  We will have a special Beer Garden set up in front of the Firehouse Tavern  where you can meet others in the group, socialize then set out and explore all that the festival has to offer.  

How it works:

From noon-3pm NYSN will have a reserved outdoor section in front of The Firehouse Tavern with tables and chairs for the group to use as a home base, eat and drink.  There will also be outdoor TV's to watch football (Giants at 1pm).Stop by anytime an meet others from the group. (Recommended time to arrive would be between noon-2pm for the largest number of people).Stroll along the festival, grab food from the vendors and restaurants, enjoy live music from several bands and more!

During the afternoon we ill be selling raffles to benefit The Marty Lyons Foundation to help grant wishes for terminally ill children.

Can I come alone?  Yes 98% of those attending will be coming on their own.  NYSN staff will be on hand to welcome you and introduce you to others.

How do I find the group?  We will have signs


What to expect:  At any given time there will be 15-20 (maybe more) people in our reserved area at any given time.  Come to socialize, then take a stroll and enjoy the festival, check out live music, eat, people watch & shop, we will be there when you get back!

What to wear: shorts, t-shirts, summer casual

What if it rains? We will send out an update

If There does not seem to be a lot of people registered on this Meet Up, are there more people going?

  Yes as explained, this event is being promoted by several Meet Up groups and

www.newyorksocialnetwork.com

.  There will be tons of people attending.  If you have any questions you can contact the event organizer directly at [masked] or call[masked]

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>
results.name: Tennis Social

results.description:
Updated September 5th, 2015

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

FALL (Sep - Nov)

As the city cools down we play four times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

There are four days that we play:

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Tuesdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!) 
- Thursdays at 5:30pm, Riverside Park (103rd and West End - Where we can!)

Damien 
[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

venue.name: Elizabeth Street Garden

results.description:
A supportive community is vital for women on a macro and micro level. Research shows the positive impact interpersonal connections have on women, their hormones and brain. Today we will discuss the following questions.

Why is it important to connect with other women deeply?

What does female support offer that we can't receive from male or child bonding?


What is the "over culture's" vested interest in keeping women separate and disconnected? (Over culture is a term coined by Clarissa Pinkola Estes which speaks about the dominate culture and it's paradigm.)

What are the ways the over culture traps us into competing with women rather than supporting each other?


What are we committed to changing in our own lives as a result of this discussion?


**I encourage everyone to leave a bit of extra time afterwards to connect with women in the group on a personal level to keep actively building community.

**Additional donations are welcome. These help to maintain the high quality facilitation and consistency of programming. 


Location: http://elizabethstreetgarden.org/
results.how_to_find_us: We will be near the back left corner of the garden. Cell: 917-717-8275

results.description:
Please read carefully: This event is being sponsored by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people registered on this Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending please contact the event host at [masked].

The Columbus Avenue Street Festival is the largest and most diverse street festival in NYC!  Unlike other street fairs, the Columbus Avenue festival features the most food options from the dozens of restaurants along Columbus Avenue. Join members of NYSN and their friends for a fun afternoon of socializing, eating, drinking, live music and football!  We will have a special Beer Garden set up in front of the Firehouse Tavern  where you can meet others in the group, socialize then set out and explore all that the festival has to offer.  

How it works:

From noon-3pm NYSN will have a reserved outdoor section in front of The Firehouse Tavern with tables and chairs for the group to use as a home base, eat and drink.  There will also be outdoor TV's to watch football (Giants at 1pm).

Stop by anytime an meet others from the group. (Recommended time to arrive would be between noon-2pm for the largest number of people).Stroll along the festival, grab food from the vendors and restaurants, enjoy live music from several bands and more!

During the afternoon we ill be selling raffles to benefit The Marty Lyons Foundation to help grant wishes for terminally ill children.

Can I come alone?  Yes 98% of those attending will be coming on their own.  NYSN staff will be on hand to welcome you and introduce you to others.

How do I find the group?  We will have signs

What to expect:  At any given time there will be 15-20 (maybe more) people in our reserved area at any given time.  Come to socialize, then take a stroll and enjoy the festival, check out live music, eat, people watch & shop, we will be there when you get back!

What to wear: shorts, t-shirts, summer casual

What if it rains? We will send out an update

If There does not seem to be a lot of people registered on this Meet Up, are there more people going?

  Yes as explained, this event is being promoted by several Meet Up groups and

www.newyorksocialnetwork.com

.  There will be tons of people attending.  If you have any questions you can contact the event organizer directly at [masked] or call[masked]

results.description:
Www.Facebook.com/bogs11510

Mabon: Your harvest-time invitation to reconnect and align with what matters. The holiday of the autumnal equinox, Harvest Home, Mabon, the Feast of the Ingathering, Meán Fómhair or Alban Elfed (in Neo-Druid traditions), is a Pagan ritual of thanksgiving for the fruits of the earth and a recognition of the need to share them to secure the blessings of the Goddess and the God during the coming winter months...

If you've been following me or my garden page on facebook, you've seen that the 'god & goddess' have been very good to us this harvest season! i'll definitely have some great treats in store for this gathering, see if you can outdo me by MAKING something even more amazing with your own two hands to share with all

The Cornucopia, or Horn of Plenty, is a traditional symbol for Mabon. It is a wonderful symbol for the wealth of harvest and is beautifully balanced symbol which is both male (phallic) and female (hollow and receptive)

this may well be the last party here of the year so it would be wonderful to see as many friends as possible and really have an outrageous spread ! I invite you to really do it up ,be creative and make

this celebration special, because it is!!! :)
Please RSVP! So i know who's coming! .

Disclaimer: this will NOT be a religious or spiritual celebration in the theological sense, i myself am atheist. just wanted to clear up any confusions there! but Molly will be in attendance with me, and mayyy be willing to go into some detail on Celtic Mythology and pagan-shamanism as those are subjects she has expertise in! it truly is fascinating and resonates very much with me.

Here's the boiler plate details:  Important info!
------------------------------------
WHAT TO BRING :
A vegan meal , Snacks or beverage to feed 5+ persons .
Beer/Wine etc welcome!
**A $10 donation will be asked of those coming empty handed.**

!!! PLEASE Bring your "Bliss-Ware" (A real plate, cup and utensils,NOT disposable) !!! We need to have a quick easy cleanup, and hope to produce Zero Garbage! that means no disposable plates/forks/cups will be here.Please don't bring them either ** If you forget,I'll have sets to rent for $5.**newbies get a pass, oldies get the riot act!

Bring drums,guitars and other instruments! bring friends & family, (have them RSVP if possible or comment with your tally)

Pets welcome!. s'long as they play nice!
kids welcome!, s'long as they don't bite.

NEW! :

1. Give-Away pile : anything you would like to pass on (that you believe someone may really want!) items not taken at the end may be disposed of so please check before you leave and retrieve!.

2. Community board: leave a card,flyer , post your haves & wants ,suggestions etc.

3.Artist Tables: do you make something(s) you'd like to display or vend? contact us !

Have an idea you think would benefit this community ? get in touch!

we can designate a space/time for talks,workshops, demos or performances. Write us with your event ideas : [masked]

results.description:
The QS World MBA Tour will be visiting New York on September 20th.

REGISTER FOR FREE

Our event is your opportunity to meet with admissions directors from the top local and international business schools, and network with top tier MBA alumni from Harvard, Wharton and NYU who will share their study and career success stories. As an attendee, you will be eligible to apply for exclusive MBA scholarships worth $1.7M and attend panels and seminars to have all of your MBA questions answered in one place. 

Our goal is to provide ambitious professionals like you with the best tools in order to facilitate your personal and professional development. We ensure that you have access to top business schools and education experts to help make this very important decision.

Attending business schools include: Cornell, Georgetown, University of Miami, George Washington University, UC Davis, UCLA, ISB, Frankfurt School of Finance and Management, Cambridge University, IESE, University of Oxford, INSEAD and more.


During this event you can:

·  Meet face-to-face with admissions directors from top international and local b-schools

·  Apply for $1.7M of exclusive MBA scholarships to help finance your MBA

·  Attend a free GMAT seminar hosted by GMAC

·  Network with top tier MBA Alumni members from top business schools from Harvard, Wharton and NYU.

Entry is free for members of this Meetup, but places are limited so make sure you Register today.  You must register via the link as well as Meetup to confirm your attendance.

We are on Twitter! Follow @TopMBA and use #QSMBAtour to join the conversation, get in touch with our team and meet other MBA candidates!

results.description:
Meet the World's Top Grad Schools in New York! 

This is an exclusive free entry offer (a saving of $15) for all The New York City Social Group Meetup members who are interested in Grad School! 

Pre-register now HERE for the QS Grad School Fair and find out how Grad School can help you fast-track your path to a thriving, enjoyable and in demand career!

Meet face-to-face with admissions directors from over 30 of the top-ranked local & international grad schools such as Imperial College London, UCLA, London Business School, HEC Paris & University of Melbourne; learn about the best Masters/PhD programs in the world & apply for exclusive scholarships! Also attend complimentary seminars from industry experts to hear their invaluable insight.

In order to gain free entry, you need to register online HERE to secure a place at the event and remember to quote “Meetup promo” at the door. 

Please note: You must register online to our event page as RSVP-ing through MeetUp does not secure free admission to the event.

Check the QS World Grad School Tour New York page for the complete list of attending grad schools, complimentary seminars and event agenda.

results.description:
CLICK HERE to Access Exclusive Free Entry to the World's Biggest MBA Fair + $1.7M Scholarships!

Or Use Our Exclusive LINK: 

http://goo.gl/vMrQPJ 

EXCLUSIVE FREE ENTRY: Achieve professional and personal development – gain personalized advice from the world’s top business schools. 


The QS World MBA Tour will be making a stop at the Hilton New York on September 20th from 12:30pm -6pm.

Our event is your opportunity to meet with admissions directors from the top local and international business schools, and network with top tier MBA alumni who will share their study and career success stories. 

As an attendee, you will be eligible to apply for exclusive MBA scholarships worth $1.7M and attend panels and seminars to have all of your MBA questions answered in one place.


Our goal is to provide ambitious professionals like you with the best tools in order to facilitate your personal and professional development. We ensure that you have access to top business schools and education experts to help make this very important decision.


During this event you can:

Meet face-to-face with admissions directors from top international and local b-schools

Apply for $1.7M of exclusive MBA scholarships to help finance your MBA

Attend a free GMAT seminar hosted by GMAC

Network with top tier MBA Alumni members from top business schools

Over 1,000 Are Expected to Attend:

Entry is free for our Meetup members up, but space is limited so make sure you Register today.


We are on Twitter! Follow @TopMBA and use #QSMBAtour to join the conversation, get in touch with our team and meet other MBA candidates!

Registration Link: http://goo.gl/vMrQPJ

results.description:
Come join us for our first-ever meetup and Sunday afternoon Hackathon!

COME LEARN SOME GOLANG! 

Each team in the Hackathon is going to build an awesome Chat application in Go and run it on one of Uber's servers to witness it taking on some real production-level traffic. Still sounds boring? Let's add a temporal paradox into the mix: how about an app that sends messages to your future self? Or an app that replays your friends' messages from the past?".

We will be covering the basics of the Go Programming language, so newcomers to Go are welcome!  Already know some go?  Get right to work with your team in coming up with your own chat app.   New to programming?  Let the organizers know, as we will be sending some "before you come" materials so you and be ready to "Go" when you get there!  (Yes, get used to Go puns!) 


After we get some workshops and some hacking done, stay for a dinner after party fun and get to know other women interested in Golang! 

Also, please let us organizers know if you would need childcare for that afternoon, we have several volunteers from Uber who are willing to make that happen!  (suh-weet, huh?!)
results.name: Inaugural meetup and Hackathon - LEARN SOME GO!

results.description:
Free. Manhattan. Sunday, September 20th @ 1:00PM

Gotham Yacht Club is looking for fun sailors and non-sailors to join us this weekend for what might be the last trip of the season!

We take trips around the Manhattan area in a 50-foot Beneteau. We usually sail the Hudson--the Statue of Liberty to the George Washington Bridge--but also go to Martha's Vineyard, the Hamptons and the Jersey Shore.

We like to fill the boat up with about 20-30 people. No sailing experience is required, but preference is given to experienced sailors since the trips can’t happen without them.  As space is limited on the boat, simply RSVP’ing “Yes” to an event does not guarantee a spot on the boat.  If a spot is available, you will be contacted directly with event details.

Sailors can take their first trip to get acquainted and enjoy the party.  From then on, sailors can choose to (1) work the morning shift and help out with the launch or (2) work the evening shift and help out with the return.  Generally, sailors spend less than a third of the trip working and can take the rest of the time to relax and socialize.

The current crew is made up of young, educated Manhattan professionals. We are looking to meet new people who will enjoy the atmosphere and company of everyone on the boat. 

If you and/or your friends are interested, please copy, paste, and fill out the questionnaire below in an email and send to [masked]. Please include your current email address so that we can contact you directly.  Since boat trips fill up in advance and we receive many applicants, we may not get back to you immediately.  

We look forward to seeing you on the water!

EVERY APPLICANT (REVELERS, SUNBATHERS, ETC.)

Q) Please provide a link to your page on Facebook or other social networking site. Please attach a picture if you don’t have a page on a social networking site.

Q) How old are you?

Q) Where did you attend school?

Q) Will you please tell us a little bit about yourself?

FOR SAILOR APPLICANTS

Q) How many days, lifetime, have you crewed on, but not captained, a sailboat?

Q) How many days, lifetime, have you captained a sailboat?

Q) How many days, lifetime, have you crewed on but not captained, a non-sailboat?

Q) How many days, lifetime, have you captained, a non-sailboat?

Q) Will you tell us a little bit about your sailing experience?


Please copy and paste all questions and answers and send in an email to [masked].

Thank you!


FAQ


Q: Do you have to pay to attend a boat party?


A: No, all boat parties are absolutely free.  You may want to bring food and drinks, which are on a potluck basis.


Q: The specific location is not listed.  Where do we meet for the boat party?


A: Unfortunately, we cannot fit everyone who RSVPs to a MeetUp event onto the boat.  There are some crew members and attendees who are not part of the MeetUp group, so there may be less space than it appears.  In order to avoid miscommunication and needing to leave people on the dock, specific details (including meeting location) are sent to members individually.  If you do not receive an invitation via email, you will not be able to attend that week’s boat party.


Q: How often are the boat parties?


A: Boat parties are generally every weekend, either on a Saturday or Sunday. They generally last all afternoon into the early evening. 


Q: Do I have to fill out the questionnaire?


A: Yes! Please fill out the questionnaire as thoroughly as possible.  If you are uncomfortable posting any of the information on your profile, please email your responses to [masked].  Without a complete application, you will not be considered to receive an invitation.  The trips last several hours, so we will have 20-30 people in a confined space for an extended period of time. Therefore, we need to have an idea of who we are inviting on the boat and ensure that we have a proper crew.  Please fill out the questionnaire if you are interested in sailing with Gotham Yacht Club.
results.name: Sunday Sailing Social, Last One?

results.description:
Receiving Guidance from the Higher Realms with Michael Rosenbaum

What if you could contact one of Masters or one of the Archangels in a meditation and ask a specific question that pertained to your life and get a clear and detailed answer?  This is exactly what I will be teaching you and practicing in this class.  Once you begin to practice this process, you can always get a spiritual answer to the issues that confront you in your life, or guidance on the most helpful direction for you to go in at this time, etc. 

In this class you will:

·  Choose a Master or Angelic guide to work with.

·  Do a process to remove any blocks you may have in receiving guidance.

·  Learn how to engage in dialogue with the higher realms, instead of being a passive listener.

·  Learn how to allow detailed information to flow through instead of just a word or a sentence.

·  Learn how to ask proper questions.

**Each participant will receive a recording of the meditation process to use at home.

Dial in Info:  [masked]

Talking Points

- What is AAT all about?

- How do you approach each trip?

- What if I'm traveling alone? How do I get a roommate?

- What should I expect of AAT?

- What does AAT expect of me?

- What should I know about Barcelona/Iceland before going?

Please come prepared with any unanswered questions!

results.description:
Baronfest, A birthday celebration of Major-General Baron von Steuben at his Jersey Estate, Historic New Bridge Landing, River Edge. 

Picket-fence Beer garden, Beer from Bergen County's own brewry Brix City Brewing, of Little Ferry WOW!, music by the Teutonic Knights. Tours are available at the barn and the three historic homes including the Zabriskie-Steuben House. Have your photo taken with Major-General Baron Von Steuben, interpretation by Paul Gleason of American Historical Theater.  Illustrated talk on Steuben at 2:30 pm by historian Kevin Wright. Food includes German fare from Paul's Pig Roast.  Also Sanducci's of River Edge & Tropical Scoops. Pony Rides in the Big Meadow by Ironside Farms (for children). Baronfest glass steins available for purchase ($5).  No rain date. Check website for updates. 

PDF description for printout. See the site map with event and building locations.


Free parking in the NJ Transit Lot. Or take the train on the Pascack Valley line to the New Bridge Landing train stop and walk one block north, see NJ Transit for schedule.    Admission, Adults: $10, Students, 6-22 years old: $7 (under 6 - free), BCHS members free. Beer, Food and Ponies - additional cost. Tickets at gate, cash line moves faster. Don't forget your photo ID. ABC Permit No. 21276.

results.description:
It may be beyond Labor Day but let's keep summer going.

On the waterfront in LIC there is a hidden jewel of a waterfront place with a great view of the water. You walk down street 44th Dr. to the end where there is not a lot of development if any / it's a little desolate. Then you hit two places on the waterfront. Go to the one on the left. The one on the right is a fancy $100 meal place. Don't go there. Anable Basin is the humble affordable place on the left.

Basically look for the fancy shack that serves beer, wine, and BBQ grill with tables on the waterfront to the left. Just remember the Beyonce Lyrics "To the left, to the left" when you get to the end of the 44th DR."

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j23mK-FdlD0

Bring cash and wear sunscreen. http://anablebasin.com/index.htm

There is no roof at this place. In the event it rains, I will move this event to Shi ( http://eatdrinkshi.com/ ) or some place with a roof in LIC such as Woodbines or Dominie's Hoek on Vernon Blvd. We will combine with Astoria Meetup that is going

http://www.meetup.com/The-Astoria-Meetup-Group/events/225206043/
results.name: Keep summer Alive! Waterfront Drinks  / Anable Basin on LIC Waterfront

NOTE! This is a MultiGroup Event. You can see the combined RSVP list at:

http://www.multigroupevents.com/events/ivy-scavenger-hunt-manhattans-highs-and-lows

  This is an event one of our members is sponsoring and they are giving us the discount code 'HSS1001' to get tickets for half price. We will meet as a group and people can form teams at the event. Tickets are normally $20. With our code you can go for half price of $10.

Event Website is at:

http://www.ivytheatre.com/scavenger-hunt-1

You must buy your tickets beforehand at:

http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?showcode=sca7E2&ss=1

Our Discount code for half price is HSS1001


----------------------------------------------------

 Uptown, downtown, cross-town, midtown; in groups of up to 4, we'll send you all around our beloved island home. Join Ivy on a scavenger hunt exploring the highs and lows of Manhattan! Snag that swag and take lots of pictures before ending at Madison Square Tavern for fantastic drink specials and crazy prizes! Get your team together, save the date, and get ready to see the best - and worst - that this city has to offer!

Why, you ask? We are raising money for PTSD awareness in the female community! We are currently devising a piece called Trigger Warning and will share the proceeds of the scavenger hunt AND the show with a super amazing charity that focuses on women's mental health.

What could be better than running around Manhattan WHILE raising money and awareness for PTSD?! The answer is nothing...nothing could possibly be better.

Sunday, September 20, 2015
2:00-7:00pm

Reflecting Pool
105 W 29th St
New York , New York 10001

results.description:
Hyatt Place is a new hotel in downtown Flushing, located just a block away from the Main St. stop of the 7 train.  It is also accessible via every bus line that goes though Flushing (Q20, Q44, Q25, Q34, Q27, Q17, Q65, Q48, Q13, Q28, Q16, Q58, Q12, Q66, Q19, Q50, Q15, Q26).

The evening's focus will be on "older," "more popular" games (such as Catan, Carcassonne, Dominion, Puerto Rico, Ticket to Ride, Power Grid, etc.) so that newer players can get a solid introduction to these new styles of board games. If your image of "board game" is Sorry, Life, Backgammon, Monopoly, Risk, etc. there's a whole new, better genre waiting for you! (Veteran games and gamers still welcome, of course.)

We are permitted to bring food into the lobby, but EVERYONE MUST BUY AT LEAST 1 THING FROM THE BAR, AND TIP THE BARTENDER VERY WELL. The venue we are using is a business and we want them to be glad to have us there.


Please keep noise level down to a minimum to avoid distracting the hotel guests and clean up after yourselves (the trash area is just a few feet away).

Note, we will be sharing a hotel bathroom key, so please do not return it to the bar until the evening is over.
results.name: Sunday Game in Flushing

results.description:
Hi all. We are going to get together for a writing session! It's our first meeting of the autumn and we are gonna have a great time!

The schedule
1) meet and greet
2) five minute free write to loosen up
3) 25 minutes on either your own project or a fiction prompt piece
4) pee break
5) 25 minutes on either your own project or a non-fiction prompt or blog post.
6) sharing, if you're comfortable. No critiques, no edits, just let it flow. Keep in mind that Little Skips can get crowded on Sunday so it's recommended that you come early. Hope to see you all there!

results.description:
Disclosure Network New York Meeting Announcement

Date: Sunday, September 20, 2015

Location: CAP 21 Studios, 18 West 18th St., (Between 5th Ave. & 6th Ave., South Side of Street), 5th Floor, Room 505, NYC.

Time: 2pm-4pm
(Please arrive 10 minutes in the lobby before 2pm meeting begins in the assigned room! Ask the Welcome Desk person for “Nick Curto's room assignment”. Try to be on time as late arrivals should be avoided if at all possible.)

Speaker: GEOFF BRADY

Topic(s): “GEOENGINEERING”

Program (live event): There are many types of geoengineering. In this presentation, Geoff Brady focuses on solar radiation management or SRM or stratospheric aerosol operations. These are the operations that deploy aircraft to release material into the atmosphere, including reflective particulates that are known to reflect the sunlight back into space. We will look at the human health effects of these operations including the blocking of the light frequency needed for creating Vitamin D in the human body. Remember, these operations are officially not happening in real time and are presented to the public as a last resort. Normal water vapor trails that are seen behind a jet dissipate within a couple minutes. Something (nanotechnology?) in the persistent trails are nucleating with particles in the upper atmosphere to create the persistent jet trails that are often dramatically displayed in the sky as grid patterns, huge X's, a smudged mess or parallel lines. Researchers have noted how "rare" sundogs, a rainbow effect around the Sun, has a refraction index of Barium, not water. As many may know, high levels of aluminum, barium and strontium, all very toxic to human health and the ecosystems, have tested positive in rain water. Geoff Brady will also present video and photographic evidence of the aerosol operations above New York City. He will share video examining the anomalies associated with these aircraft spraying the persistent trails. Anomalies include aircraft morphing and UFOs near aircraft.

Bio: Geoff Brady is a radio producer and host of In Other News, a radio show broadcast on WBAI 99.5 FM and on Pacifica affiliate stations as well as Dark Matter Radio. His radio documentary Climate Engineers: War, Profit and Survival aired across Pacifica Radio affiliate stations in 2006 and in it the question was asked, “How can global warming be accurately assessed when operations are conducted to occlude the Sun, heat the atmosphere and alter the jet stream?” www.inothernewsradio.com

Please plan to attend what is bound to be one of the most interesting DNNY meetings to date and invite your interested friends to join us!

For questions/comments please contact: Nick Curto, DNNY Director/Co-Founder
E-mail: [masked] Phone[masked]

Meeting Details: Admission $10 per person. Children 12 and under admitted free. Our treasurer will collect your admission fee in the meeting room before the program begins.
R.S.V.P. Strongly recommended for people attending the meeting for the first time. Provide full name, e-mail address and cell phone number per person.

3 Important Notes:

1. No food or beverages are allowed in any rooms of the venue except bottled water that may be brought into the venue. You can also purchase chilled bottled water at the Welcome Desk in the Lobby for $1.
2. Please silence your cell phones when entering the meeting room.
3. No photos may be taken or sound recording is ever allowed at any of the DNNY meetings.

results.name: Next DNNY Meeting event: Sunday, Sept. 20, 2pm!

results.description:
Using the time honored traditions of fermentation, you will learn how to preserve fresh produce so that you can reduce food waste, save money, and eat local throughout the year. We'll discuss the theory and practice of fermentation as well as the healing qualities and nutritional importance of probiotic fermented foods.


Each participant will get to make a jar of fermented vegetables. Handouts with instructions and recipes will be provided so you feel comfortable fermenting at home.


Fee: $45 to register, plus a $10 materials fee which is payable in cash on the day of the class. Pre-registration is highly recommended: http://thecommonsbrooklyn.org/civicrm/event/info?reset=1&id=12964


About the instructor:

Angela Davis is a Holistic Health Coach, Certified Healing Foods Specialist, and the owner of Nourishing Works Holistic Health and Wellness Coaching. She is also the Food Education Manager for Just Food, a New York City based nonprofit organization that empowers and supports community leaders in their efforts to increase access to locally grown food, especially in underserved New York City neighborhoods. Angela has been making homemade fermented foods since 2007 and serves as the co-organizer of NYC Ferments, a monthly Meet-Up of fermentation enthusiasts.
results.name: Preserving the Harvest: How to Make Sauerkraut and Fermented Veggies

results.description:
Come meet  Laura Theodore, the award-winning host of the PBS cooking show Jazzy Vegetarian!Laura will be joining us at Watchung Booksellers at 2:00pm on Sunday, September 20th. She will be discussing her new book Vegan-Ease. There will be books available for purchase, and Laura will be happy to sign your copy. 

Choosing a plant-based diet is made deliciously easy with Laura Theodore’s Vegan-Ease: An Easy Guide to Enjoying a Plant-Based Diet, a new approach to living vegan. Written by Laura Theodore, this comprehensive guide is suitable for novice cooks and long-time vegans alike, offering more than 130 step-by-step, wholesome, “eco-nomical,” and satisfying recipes that are quick and easy, each complete with nutritional analysis. Enhanced by over 200 gorgeous, full-color photographs, each recipe is ranked with an Ease-Factor to make it easy to choose recipes that fit into any busy schedule, using ingredients already on hand. This cookbook and guideincludes all you need to know to embrace a cost-saving, healthier lifestyle for you and your family. 

Laura Theodore is a TASTE award-winning, recognized public television personality, vegan chef, radio host, cookbook author and recording artist. Ms. Theodore is author of Laura Theodore's Vegan-Ease: An Easy Guide to Enjoying a Plant-Based Diet and two previous cookbooks: Jazzy Vegetarian Classics and Jazzy Vegetarian. Laura is the on-camera host of the highly successful, award-winning Jazzy Vegetarian cooking series on public television, presently available in over 88% of US households nationwide. Ms. Theodore hosts the popular podcast radio show, Jazzy Vegetarian Radio, now in its seventh year. In addition, Laura has made guest appearances on ABC, NBC, CBS and FOX, and was recently featured on The Talk on CBS, Insider/Entertainment Tonight (HBO Red Carpet), News 4-NBC, Fox News 8, The Better Show (BVN) and the WCBS Health & Wellbeing Report. Laura writes a weekly food column for Mother Earth Living and she has been featured in the New York Times, New York Daily News, VegNews, Family Circle, Readers Digest, PBS Food, Naked Food and Healthy Aging, among other highly respected news, food and lifestyle-related journals.
results.name: Laura Theodore Talk and Book Signing

results.description:
Here it is, the most anticipated book in a long, long time. Hopefully, by September we can all have gotten our hands on this title.

Originally written in the mid-1950s, Go Set a Watchman was the novel Harper Lee first submitted to her publishers before To Kill a Mockingbird. Assumed to have been lost, the manuscript was discovered in late 2014.

Go Set a Watchman features many of the characters from To Kill a Mockingbird some twenty years later. Returning home to Maycomb to visit her father, Jean Louise Finch—Scout—struggles with issues both personal and political, involving Atticus, society, and the small Alabama town that shaped her.

Exploring how the characters from To Kill a Mockingbird are adjusting to the turbulent events transforming mid-1950s America, Go Set a Watchman casts a fascinating new light on Harper Lee’s enduring classic. Moving, funny and compelling, it stands as a magnificent novel in its own right.
results.name: "Go Set A Watchman", by Harper Lee

results.description:
This month's book is Uprooted by Naomi Novik.

Agnieszka loves her valley home, her quiet village, the forests and the bright shining river. But the corrupted Wood stands on the border, full of malevolent power, and its shadow lies over her life.

Her people rely on the cold, driven wizard known only as the Dragon to keep its powers at bay. But he demands a terrible price for his help: one young woman handed over to serve him for ten years, a fate almost as terrible as falling to the Wood.

The next choosing is fast approaching, and Agnieszka is afraid. She knows—everyone knows—that the Dragon will take Kasia: beautiful, graceful, brave Kasia, all the things Agnieszka isn’t, and her dearest friend in the world. And there is no way to save her.

But Agnieszka fears the wrong things. For when the Dragon comes, it is not Kasia he will choose.

This book is available at Amazon, Barnes & Noble, or Kobo, digital or otherwise.

* * *


IMPORTANT RSVP POLICY

If you RSVP and find you cannot make it, please change your RSVP so that we are not waiting for you. Please change it no less than two hours before the scheduled meeting time. If you RSVP and do not show, you will have to pay $10 when you attend your next event. This is to prevent those on the waiting list from missing out on an event.

The RSVP policy is the same as for the general meetup. Please see the entire policy here:
http://www.meetup.com/NYSciFi-Fantasy/pages/Membership_Policy/


* * *


Questions and answers!

Where will we be meeting?

We will be meeting at the Citigroup Atrium.

There's an entrance at 53rd and Lexington Avenue off the 53rd and Lex subway stop. You have to go down the steps; the subway station will be on your right and the Atrium will be straight in front of you. The doors are labeled.

There is a Barnes and Noble (with a Starbucks inside) on the next level up at 54th and 3rd. If you enter through the B&N, you will need to go through B&N (up a few steps from the entrance), past the NOOK display to the glass doors and down the escalator to the atrium.

There is a lift down the stairs on the right side of the corridor as you're coming from the fountain.

There's also free wi-fi and restrooms if you need them.

How will I recognize the group when I get there?

We're generally pretty easy for newcomers to recognize--if in doubt, look for paper copies of the book on tables, or a group of excited-looking people with lots of electronic reading devices. We'll try to recognize you from your picture; if in doubt, feel free to walk up and ask people!

Do I need to finish the whole book?

Nope! You're welcome to come either way. However, the whole book is fair game for discussion, including the ending!

How are the books chosen?

We try to select the next book and date of the meetup after we're finished discussing the book. We sometimes do this by poll, selected from the attendees' suggestions -- if so, the attendees will be invited to vote on the website by email. Sometimes we'll all jump on an appealing suggestion, or sometimes I'll get bored of posting polls and just pick one by fiat.

What books has the club read in the past?

We've compiled a list. (Thanks to Sarah for compiling this for us!)

I have another question!

You're welcome to message me through the website, or comment here. 

Thanks for signing up, and I hope to see you there!

Also, join our Goodreads group!

http://www.goodreads.com/group/show/57070.NY_Fantasy_Book_Club
results.name: Fantasy Book Club: Uprooted by Naomi Novik

results.description:
First day at new location: Paramus, New Jersey; Mariann's School of Dance!

We explore energy cultivation practices in a free, open environment.

Shen Shing Qigong, Energy Cultivation through Spiritual Movement, involves gentle motion engineered to exercise our energetic physiology, with Body, Mind and Spirit as One. Through development of smooth, vigorous energy circulation, meditative movement helps us cultivate discoveries we can make in our unique journeys, such as robust health, blossoming awareness, spiritual awakening, sensitivity to energy, and expanded perception, with infinite potential.  The practice has been passed on for around 2500 years since its origination by Wang Zi Qiao in ancient China.

Zen Meditation as well fosters exploration of consciousness, posture, and energy circulation and harmonics.  Glen Matsuda of Rockland Aikido is facilitating Zen.  He shares his knowledge and experience from 45 years of practice and may incorporate some gentle Aikido exercises into the meetup as well.  Aikido means The Way of Harmonious Energy and was founded in the 20th century by Morihei Ueshiba, who wished to promote peace, love, and happiness in the changing world.

I began learning traditional arts in 2003 and transitioned to Qigong in 2010.  Since then I have pursued Spirituality, energy cultivation, happiness and health with fantastic outcomes.  I also studied Oriental Health theory at Tri-State College of Acupuncture and Pacific College of Oriental Medicine.  Now I am beginning in Aikido practice.  Glen and I continue to evolve and bring this Spirit to the meetups.  It's an open environment where we can all share our experiences and learn together.

I am happy, introducing these peaceful, joyous arts to you.

There are some people coming who aren't RSVPing on the meetup site.

We're welcoming contributions to help support us!  : )  We're requesting a flexible amount of $20 each day, accepted online or in the small glass bowl at the meetup; we're grateful for any amount you're comfortable with, and simply your choice of involvement; you're always welcome.

--Justin Derringer

results.description:
Greenwich Village in Manhattan is a community with a global history and reputation. The quiet streets of the area have been the stage for creative and social movements that today give shape to the unique American character. The area started out as farm territory and later became an immigrant community. In the first half of the 20th century the area was inhabited by some of the greatest creative minds of American Culture. Today the area retains its cultural essence in diverse aspects and the public art and architecture contrast richly with the greater metropolitan environment of NYC.

Itinerary:
• Father Demo Square
• Bleecker Street
• Cherry Lane Theater
• Sheridan Square
• Cafe Wha?
• Washington Square Park
• New York University
• And Much More

Reservations: 
Please RSVP.If you later realize you will not be able to attend please change your reservation.

Where:
Participants meet with the guide ten minutes before tour begins at father Demo Square on 6th Av. and Bleecker St. map here. Tour concludes at Washington Square Park map here.

Cost: 
This tour has a market value of $20 per person. You are not charged. At the end of the tour you can put a value to the information presented in the form of a gratuity.

Some of the Sights we will experience:

More details:http://www.theidproject.org/events/2015/05/03/sundays-weekly-introduction-meditation 

Recent scientific research suggests that meditation practice is an effective means to lessening stress and depression, boosting bodily immune and respiratory functions, increasing happiness and cultivating compassion and joy within one's life.

Please arrive by 2:50 to settle into your seat for the program. Chairs and cushions will be available. We request a $5-$10 donation to support our organization, though no one will be turned away for lack of funds. 

Note we are located on the 2nd Floor of a walkup building.  We have no elevator. 

The Interdependence Project 
302 Bowery 3rd Floor, Middle Buzzer 
Between Houston and 1st Street

results.description:
Before you RSVP,  please consider that this group (where events are purposefully small in size) is not like other Meetup groups where you can feel anonymous.  Simply not showing up (or cancelling at the last minute) does affect the host and other attendees.  I understand that things happen.  All I ask is that if you can no longer attend, or have a strong sense you will be held up at work or with family issues, that you give me Two Hours notice.  Anyone who simply does not show up or give me sufficient notice that they can no longer make the event (or else who doesn't provide a damn good explanation and profuse apology after the fact ....lol), will have to be removed from the group.  I don't do this to be a taskmaster or anything...it's just very disheartening for me to pay Meetup Organizer dues,  arrange events, provide very detailed information on events to the group, and then for me to arrive at the venue, only to find a bunch of no-shows.  All I ask is for common courtesy.  Thank you for your understanding!!  ;-)

Also, to help offset the fees that I must pay to Meetup.com each month as a Group Organizer, I'd like to kindly ask for a $3 donation from each member, whenever they attend one of our events.  Thank you!

+++++++++++++

Now for the fun part...

+++++++++++++

General overview

This lesson will be taught by me, on my Astoria rooftop!  This class will focus on OUTDOOR gardening.  It doesn't matter whether your outdoor space is sunny or shady, so long as you have some type of outdoor space to grown a plant or two.

I love gardening, and have been doing so for about 13 years now...totally self-taught.

This lesson will assume that you know little to nothing about gardening, and will cover everything from how to decide what plants might work for you based upon your garden's location (ground-level patio?  elevated balcony?  shade?  sun?), the best places (local shops and online sources) to buy seeds/plants/other garden supplies, HOW to properly pot a plant, overall design ideas for your outdoor space, etc. As part of the class, I'll do a demo where I'll actually move an existing plant into a larger pot, and show the proper technique for doing so. I'll also show how to plant seeds (it's simple really...but there is a bit of 'technique' depending on how small or large the actual seeds are....)

+++++++++++++++

Do we need to bring anything?

This lesson will be a listen and observe type thing so 'no', you don't need to bring anything.

If however you are interested in growing your own kale, I have organic kale seeds I can provide to anyone who's interested. (Kale is a very hardy plant which can continue to grow throughout much of the Fall and even through milder Winter months.  If your outdoor space is mostly Shade however, Kale will not grow.) If you want me to sow your kale seeds during our lesson, you are welcome to bring your own pot (make sure the pot is PLASTIC or RESIN, has DRAINAGE HOLES in the bottom, and make sure the pot is 8-12" in diameter), along with potting soil already in the pot.   (Keep in mind you'll then need to carry this same pot back home, and it will be a bit heavier after we sow your seeds and add water.)

++++++++++++++++

What happens after the lesson?

After the lesson I can email folks with some key useful info such as good sources for seeds, plants, supplies, and garden decorations.  I can also give the names of some websites that are loaded with good information and advice.  And lastly, if anyone needs help with their garden once it's up and running, I'm always happy to help out!

DESCRIPTION:

Our games are for levels and people that prefer to play a competitive game of soccer, break a sweat while exercising running up and down the field with the ball and all this happening in a very laid-back and non-judgmental environment. Please, arrive 10 minutes before the game so we can get the teams set up.

There will be 2 teams on the field and we will play TWO games, 30 minutes/Halves. At the end of the first 30 minutes we will have a short break and teams will switch to play again. Please check your email or our meetup message board on friday night or before 12.00pm on Saturday to see what team you are on. This will save us a lot of time on the field.

RULES OF THE GAME:

First and most important rule of the game is to have fun and enjoy the time on the field! Rough play and offensive language will absolutely not be tolerated!!! In plain words, no slide tackling, no pushing and no telling off.

Power shots allowed, just please don't do it 5 feet away from goal.

If you don't sign up for the game, do not show up.

If you are late for the game, you must wait until the game in progress is over to join your team.

Those that don't comply with these rules, will kindly be asked to leave the field so others can enjoy the game and maybe a two game ban.

Any other questions regarding the rules of the game or anything else, should be directed to the organizer directly or to the assistant organizer/s!!!

Take A, C or E to 23rd St and 8th Ave and walk to 10th Ave and 27th St or any subway line to 34th St and Penn Station and walk for about 8 minutes to 28th St and 10th Ave.

What to bring with you:

A pair of sneakers, indoor or turf shoes, shin guards (recommended) and lots of water. There is a water fountain next to the park if you need extra water.

Fee:

You will be asked to pay $9.25 when you RSVP. This $9.25 is used to pay for, facilities permits, meetup fees, Amazon fees, goals, cones, soccer balls etc.

Refunds & Weather Policy:
